         <td>right</td>
       </tr><tr>
         <th colspan="2">Calling code</th>
         <td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Telephone_numbers_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Telephone numbers in Germany (page does not exist)">49</a></td>
       </tr><tr>
         <th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th>
         <td><a href="/wiki/.de" title=".de">.de</a>&#160;<sup class="reference plainlinks nourlexpansion" id="ref_b"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://ec2-54-166-234-74.compute-1.amazonaws.com:8080/wiki/Germany#endnote_b">[2]</a></sup></td>
       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_a"><b><a href="#ref_a">^</a></b></span>  <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sorbian_languages" title="Sorbian languages">Sorbian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Romany</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Frisian_languages" title="Frisian languages">Frisian</a> are officially recognised by the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages (ECRML)</a>.</td>
       </tr><tr style="font-size:xx-small;" class="mergedbottomrow">
         <td align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lower (page does not exist)">Template:Lower</a></td>
         <td colspan="2" style="padding-left:0;"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_b"><b><a href="#ref_b">^</a></b></span>  The <a href="/wiki/.eu" title=".eu">.eu</a> domain is also used, as it is shared with other <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> member states.</td>
       </tr></table>
<p><b>Germany</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-de (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-de</a>), officially the <b>Federal Republic of Germany</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-de (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-de</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPA-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPA-de (page does not exist)">Template:IPA-de</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parliamentary_republic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parliamentary republic (page does not exist)">parliamentary republic</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">western</a>-<a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">central Europe</a>. The country consists of <a href="/wiki/States_of_Germany" title="States of Germany">16 states</a> and its capital and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_in_Germany_by_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities in Germany by population (page does not exist)">largest city</a> is <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>. Germany covers an area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and has a largely temperate seasonal climate. With 80.6&#160;million inhabitants, it is the most populous member state in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. Germany is the major economic and political power of the European continent and a historic leader in many cultural, theoretical and technical fields.
</p><p>Various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germanic_tribes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germanic tribes (page does not exist)">Germanic tribes</a> occupied what is now northern Germany and southern Scandinavia since <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical antiquity</a>. A region named <a href="/wiki/Germania" title="Germania">Germania</a> was <a href="/wiki/Germania_(book)" title="Germania (book)">documented</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> before AD&#160;100. During the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">Migration Period</a> that coincided with the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Decline of the Roman Empire">decline of the Roman Empire</a>, the Germanic tribes expanded southward and established kingdoms throughout much of Europe. Beginning in the 10th century, German territories formed a central part of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> During the 16th century, northern German regions became the centre of the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>. Occupied during the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, the rise of <a href="/wiki/Pan-Germanism" title="Pan-Germanism">Pan-Germanism</a> inside the <a href="/wiki/German_Confederation" title="German Confederation">German Confederation</a> resulted in the <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Germany" title="Unification of Germany">unification of most of the German states</a> in 1871 into the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a>, which was dominated by <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>.
</p><p>After the <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Revolution of 1918–1919 (page does not exist)">German Revolution of 1918–1919</a> and the subsequent military surrender in <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>, the Empire was replaced by the parliamentary <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a> in 1918, with some of its territory partitioned in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>. Despite its lead in many scientific and cultural fields at this time, Germany nonetheless endured significant economic and political instability, which intensified during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a> and contributed to <a href="/wiki/Machtergreifung" title="Machtergreifung">the establishment</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Third Reich</a> in 1933. The subsequent rise of <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascism</a> led to <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. After 1945, Germany was divided by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Allied-occupied_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allied-occupied Germany (page does not exist)">allied occupation</a>, and evolved into two states, <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a>. In 1990, the country was <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">reunified</a>.
</p><p>Germany has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fourth-largest economy by nominal GDP</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fifth-largest by purchasing power parity</a>. As a global leader in several industrial and technological sectors, it is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_exports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by exports (page does not exist)">second-largest exporter</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_imports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by imports (page does not exist)">third-largest importer</a> of goods. It is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by Human Development Index (page does not exist)">very high standard of living</a>, featuring comprehensive <a href="/wiki/Social_security" title="Social security">social security</a> that includes the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system. Known for its rich <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Germany" title="Culture of Germany">cultural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Germany" title="Politics of Germany">political</a> <a href="/wiki/History_of_Germany" title="History of Germany">history</a>, Germany has been the home of many influential <a href="/wiki/German_philosophy" title="German philosophy">philosophers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Germany" title="Music of Germany">music composers</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Science_and_technology_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Science and technology in Germany (page does not exist)">scientists, and inventors</a>. Germany was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Community</a> in 1957, which became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> in 1993. It is part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schengen_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schengen Area (page does not exist)">Schengen Area</a>, and has been a member of the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> since 1999. Germany is a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> in regional and global affairs, and is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (page does not exist)">OECD</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The English word <i>Germany</i> derives from the Latin <a href="/wiki/Germania" title="Germania">Germania</a>, which came into use after <a href="/wiki/Julius_Caesar" title="Julius Caesar">Julius Caesar</a> adopted it for the peoples east of the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a> term <i>Deutschland</i> (originally <i>diutisciu land</i>, "the German lands") is derived from <i><a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/deutsch#German" class="extiw" title="wikt:deutsch">deutsch</a></i>, descended from <a href="/wiki/Old_High_German" title="Old High German">Old High German</a> <i>diutisc</i> "popular" (i.e. belonging to the <i>diot</i> or <i>diota</i> "people"), originally used to distinguish the <a href="/wiki/Vernacular" title="Vernacular">language of the common people</a> from <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> and its <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance descendants</a>. This in turn descends from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Proto-Germanic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Proto-Germanic (page does not exist)">Proto-Germanic</a> <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Proto-Germanic/%C3%BEiudiskaz" class="extiw" title="wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/þiudiskaz">*<i>þiudiskaz</i></a> "popular" (see also the Latinised form <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theodiscus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theodiscus (page does not exist)">Theodiscus</a>), derived from <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Proto-Germanic/%C3%BEeud%C5%8D" class="extiw" title="wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/þeudō">*<i>þeudō</i></a>, descended from <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">Proto-Indo-European</a> <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Appendix:Proto-Indo-European/tewt%C3%A9h%E2%82%82" class="extiw" title="wikt:Appendix:Proto-Indo-European/tewtéh₂">*<i>tewtéh₂-</i></a> "people".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Germanic_tribes_and_Frankish_Empire">Germanic tribes and Frankish Empire</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Invasions_of_the_Roman_Empire_1.png" title="File:Invasions of the Roman Empire 1.png">File:Invasions of the Roman Empire 1.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Basic view of second- to fifth-century migrations</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic tribes</a> are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnogenesis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnogenesis (page does not exist)">thought to date from</a> the <a href="/wiki/Nordic_Bronze_Age" title="Nordic Bronze Age">Nordic Bronze Age</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Roman_Iron_Age" title="Pre-Roman Iron Age">Pre-Roman Iron Age</a>. From southern Scandinavia and north Germany, they expanded south, east and west from the 1st century&#160;BC, coming into contact with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Celt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Celt (page does not exist)">Celtic</a> tribes of <a href="/wiki/Gaul" title="Gaul">Gaul</a> as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iranian_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iranian peoples (page does not exist)">Iranian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balts" title="Balts">Baltic</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slavic_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slavic peoples (page does not exist)">Slavic</a> tribes in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Under <a href="/wiki/Augustus" title="Augustus">Augustus</a>, Rome began to invade Germania (an area extending roughly from the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>). In AD&#160;9, three <a href="/wiki/Roman_legion" title="Roman legion">Roman legions</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Publius_Quinctilius_Varus" title="Publius Quinctilius Varus">Publius Quinctilius Varus</a> were <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Teutoburg_Forest" title="Battle of the Teutoburg Forest">defeated</a> by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheruscan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheruscan (page does not exist)">Cheruscan</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Arminius" title="Arminius">Arminius</a>. By AD&#160;100, when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tacitus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tacitus (page does not exist)">Tacitus</a> wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Germania_(book)" title="Germania (book)">Germania</a></i>, Germanic tribes had settled along the Rhine and the Danube (the <a href="/wiki/Limes_Germanicus" title="Limes Germanicus">Limes Germanicus</a>), occupying most of the area of modern Germany; Austria, southern <a href="/wiki/Bavaria" title="Bavaria">Bavaria</a> and the western <a href="/wiki/Rhineland" title="Rhineland">Rhineland</a>, however, were Roman provinces.<sup id="cite_ref-9-13_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9-13-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 3rd century a number of large West Germanic tribes emerged: <a href="/wiki/Alemanni" title="Alemanni">Alemanni</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Franks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Franks (page does not exist)">Franks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chatti" title="Chatti">Chatti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saxons" title="Saxons">Saxons</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frisii&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frisii (page does not exist)">Frisii</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sicambri" title="Sicambri">Sicambri</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Thuringii" title="Thuringii">Thuringii</a>. Around 260, the Germanic peoples broke into Roman-controlled lands.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> After the invasion of the <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a> in 375, and with the decline of Rome from 395, Germanic tribes moved further south-west. Simultaneously several large tribes formed in what is now Germany and displaced the smaller Germanic tribes. Large areas (known since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Merovingian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Merovingian (page does not exist)">Merovingian</a> period as <a href="/wiki/Austrasia" title="Austrasia">Austrasia</a>) were <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">occupied by the Franks</a>, and Northern Germany was ruled by the Saxons and Slavs.<sup id="cite_ref-9-13_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9-13-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holy_Roman_Empire">Holy Roman Empire</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>On 25 December 800, the Frankish king <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a> was crowned emperor and founded the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Empire" title="Carolingian Empire">Carolingian Empire</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Verdun" title="Treaty of Verdun">divided in 843</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-f11_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f11-17">[17]</a></sup> The Holy Roman Empire resulted from the <a href="/wiki/East_Francia" title="East Francia">eastern portion</a> of this division. Its territory stretched from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eider_River&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eider River (page does not exist)">Eider River</a> in the north to the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> coast in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-f11_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-f11-17">[17]</a></sup> Under the reign of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ottonian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ottonian (page does not exist)">Ottonian</a> emperors (919–1024), several major <a href="/wiki/Stem_duchy" title="Stem duchy">duchies</a> were consolidated, and the German king <a href="/w/index.php?title=Otto_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Otto I (page does not exist)">Otto I</a> was crowned <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a> of these regions in 962. In 996 <a href="/wiki/Gregory_V" title="Gregory V">Gregory V</a> became the first German Pope, appointed by his cousin <a href="/wiki/Otto_III" title="Otto III" class="mw-redirect">Otto III</a>, whom he shortly after crowned <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The Holy Roman Empire absorbed northern Italy and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burgundy_(historical_region)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burgundy (historical region) (page does not exist)">Burgundy</a> under the reign of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salian (page does not exist)">Salian</a> emperors (1024–1125), although the emperors lost power through the <a href="/wiki/Investiture_Controversy" title="Investiture Controversy">Investiture Controversy</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Martin_Luther_by_Lucas_Cranach_der_%C3%84ltere.jpeg" title="File:Martin Luther by Lucas Cranach der Ältere.jpeg">File:Martin Luther by Lucas Cranach der Ältere.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther (page does not exist)">Martin Luther</a> initiated the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a></div></div></div>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hohenstaufen" title="House of Hohenstaufen">Hohenstaufen</a> emperors (1138–1254), the German princes increased their influence further south and east into territories inhabited by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slavic_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slavic peoples (page does not exist)">Slavs</a>, preceding <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_German_settlement_in_Central_and_Eastern_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of German settlement in Central and Eastern Europe (page does not exist)">German settlement</a> in these areas and further east <i>(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ostsiedlung&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ostsiedlung (page does not exist)">Ostsiedlung</a>)</i>. Northern German towns grew prosperous as members of the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> Starting with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Famine_of_1315%E2%80%931317&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Famine of 1315–1317 (page does not exist)">Great Famine</a> in 1315, then the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> of 1348–50, the population of Germany plummeted.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> The edict of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bull_of_1356" title="Golden Bull of 1356">Golden Bull</a> in 1356 provided the basic constitution of the empire and codified the election of the emperor by seven <a href="/wiki/Prince-elector" title="Prince-elector">prince-electors</a> who ruled some of the most powerful principalities and archbishoprics.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther (page does not exist)">Martin Luther</a> publicised <a href="/wiki/The_Ninety-Five_Theses" title="The Ninety-Five Theses">The Ninety-Five Theses</a> in 1517 in Wittenberg, challenging the beliefs of the Roman Catholic Church and initiating the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a>. A separate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lutheranism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lutheranism (page does not exist)">Lutheran</a> church became the official religion in many German states after 1530. Religious conflict led to the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War" title="Thirty Years' War">Thirty Years' War</a> (1618–1648), which devastated German lands.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> The population of the German states was reduced by about 30%.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Westphalia" title="Peace of Westphalia">Peace of Westphalia</a> (1648) ended religious warfare among the German states, but the empire was <i>de facto</i> divided into numerous independent principalities. In the 18th century, the Holy Roman Empire consisted of approximately 1,800 such <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_in_the_Holy_Roman_Empire" title="List of states in the Holy Roman Empire">territories</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1740 onwards, <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_dualism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German dualism (page does not exist)">dualism</a> between the Austrian <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> dominated German history. In 1806, the <i>Imperium</i> was overrun and dissolved as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Confederation_and_Empire">German Confederation and Empire</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maerz1848_berlin.jpg" title="File:Maerz1848 berlin.jpg">File:Maerz1848 berlin.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Origin of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Germany" title="Flag of Germany">Black-Red-Gold</a>: <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848_in_the_German_states" title="Revolutions of 1848 in the German states">German Revolution of 1848</a> (<a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, 19 March 1848)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wernerprokla.jpg" title="File:Wernerprokla.jpg">File:Wernerprokla.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Foundation of the <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">German Empire</a> in <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Versailles</a>, 1871. <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck" title="Otto von Bismarck">Bismarck</a> is at the center in a white uniform</div></div></div>
<p>Following the fall of <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> convened in 1814 and founded the German Confederation (Deutscher Bund), a loose league of <a href="/wiki/States_of_the_German_Confederation" title="States of the German Confederation">39 sovereign states</a>. Disagreement with <a href="/wiki/European_Restoration" title="European Restoration" class="mw-redirect">restoration</a> politics partly led to the rise of <a href="/wiki/Liberalism_in_Germany" title="Liberalism in Germany">liberal</a> movements, followed by new measures of repression by Austrian statesman <a href="/wiki/Klemens_von_Metternich" title="Klemens von Metternich">Metternich</a>. The <i><a href="/wiki/Zollverein" title="Zollverein">Zollverein</a></i>, a tariff union, furthered economic unity in the German states.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nationalism" title="Nationalism">National</a> and liberal ideals of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a> gained increasing support among many, especially young, Germans. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hambach_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hambach Festival (page does not exist)">Hambach Festival</a> in May 1832 was a main event in support of <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_question&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German question (page does not exist)">German unity</a>, freedom and democracy. In the light of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolutions_of_1848&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolutions of 1848 (page does not exist)">series of revolutionary movements in Europe</a>, which established a republic <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Revolution_of_1848&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Revolution of 1848 (page does not exist)">in France</a>, intellectuals and commoners started the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848_in_the_German_states" title="Revolutions of 1848 in the German states">Revolutions of 1848 in the German states</a>. King <a href="/wiki/Frederick_William_IV_of_Prussia" title="Frederick William IV of Prussia">Frederick William IV of Prussia</a> was offered the title of Emperor, but with a loss of power; he rejected the crown and the proposed constitution, leading to a temporary setback for the movement.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Conflict between King <a href="/wiki/William_I,_German_Emperor" title="William I, German Emperor">William I</a> of Prussia and the increasingly liberal parliament erupted over military reforms in 1862, and the king appointed <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck" title="Otto von Bismarck">Otto von Bismarck</a> the new <a href="/wiki/Minister_President_of_Prussia" title="Minister President of Prussia">Minister President of Prussia</a>. Bismarck successfully waged <a href="/wiki/Second_Schleswig_War" title="Second Schleswig War">war on Denmark</a> in 1864. Prussian victory in the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Prussian_War" title="Austro-Prussian War">Austro-Prussian War</a> of 1866 enabled him to create the <a href="/wiki/North_German_Confederation" title="North German Confederation">North German Confederation</a> (Norddeutscher Bund) and to exclude <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Austria</a>, formerly the leading German state, from the federation's affairs. After the French defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Franco-Prussian_War" title="Franco-Prussian War">Franco-Prussian War</a>, the German Empire was proclaimed in 1871 in <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Versailles" title="Palace of Versailles">Versailles</a>, uniting all scattered parts of Germany except Austria (<span lang="de"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=German_question&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German question (page does not exist)">Kleindeutschland</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, or "Lesser Germany").
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:German_Reich1.png" title="File:German Reich1.png">File:German Reich1.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Imperial Germany (1871–1918), with the dominant <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> in blue</div></div></div>
<p>With almost two-thirds of its territory and population, Prussia was the dominating constituent of the new state; the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hohenzollern" title="House of Hohenzollern">Hohenzollern</a> King of Prussia ruled as its concurrent Emperor, and Berlin became its capital.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup> In the <span lang="de"><i><a href="/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnderzeit" title="Gründerzeit">Gründerzeit</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> period following the <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Germany" title="Unification of Germany">unification of Germany</a>, Bismarck's foreign policy as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chancellor_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chancellor of Germany (page does not exist)">Chancellor of Germany</a> under Emperor William I secured Germany's position as a great nation by forging alliances, isolating <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a> by diplomatic means, and avoiding war. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Conference" title="Berlin Conference">Berlin Conference</a> in 1884 Germany claimed several <a href="/wiki/List_of_former_German_colonies" title="List of former German colonies">colonies</a> including <a href="/wiki/German_East_Africa" title="German East Africa">German East Africa</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_South-West_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German South-West Africa (page does not exist)">German South-West Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Togoland" title="Togoland">Togo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cameroon" title="Cameroon">Cameroon</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> Under <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_II,_German_Emperor" title="Wilhelm II, German Emperor">Wilhelm II</a>, however, Germany, like other European powers, took an <a href="/wiki/New_Imperialism" title="New Imperialism">imperialistic</a> course leading to friction with neighbouring countries. Most alliances in which Germany had previously been involved were not renewed, and new alliances excluded the country.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Assassination_of_Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria (page does not exist)">assassination</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria (page does not exist)">Austria's crown prince</a> on 28 June 1914 triggered <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">World War I</a>. Germany, as part of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a>, suffered defeat against the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">one of the bloodiest</a> conflicts of all time. An estimated two million German soldiers died in World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%931919&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Revolution of 1918–1919 (page does not exist)">German Revolution</a> broke out in November 1918, and Emperor Wilhelm II and all German ruling princes <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abdication&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abdication (page does not exist)">abdicated</a>. An <a href="/wiki/Armistice_with_Germany" title="Armistice with Germany">armistice</a> ended the war on 11 November, and Germany was forced to sign the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a> in June 1919. The treaty was perceived in Germany as a humiliating continuation of the war, and is often cited as an influence in the rise of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nazism (page does not exist)">Nazism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Weimar_Republic_and_Nazi_Regime">Weimar Republic and Nazi Regime</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-S33882,_Adolf_Hitler_retouched.jpg" title="File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-S33882, Adolf Hitler retouched.jpg">File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-S33882, Adolf Hitler retouched.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/F%C3%BChrer" title="Führer">Führer</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a></div></div></div>
<p>At the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/German_Revolution_of_1918%E2%80%9319" title="German Revolution of 1918–19">German Revolution</a> in November 1918, Germany was declared a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a>. However, the struggle for power continued, with radical-left <a href="/wiki/Communists" title="Communists" class="mw-redirect">Communists</a> <a href="/wiki/Bavarian_Soviet_Republic" title="Bavarian Soviet Republic">seizing power in Bavaria</a>. The revolution came to an end on 11 August 1919, when the democratic <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Constitution" title="Weimar Constitution">Weimar Constitution</a> was signed by <a href="/wiki/President_of_Germany" title="President of Germany">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Ebert" title="Friedrich Ebert">Friedrich Ebert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> An era of increasing national confidence, a very liberal cultural life and decade of economic prosperity followed - known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Twenties&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Twenties (page does not exist)">Golden Twenties</a>.
Suffering from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a> of 1929, the harsh peace conditions dictated by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>, and a long succession of unstable governments, Germans increasingly lacked identification with the government in the early 1930s. This was exacerbated by a widespread right-wing <span lang="de"><i>Dolchstoßlegende</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stab-in-the-back_legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stab-in-the-back legend (page does not exist)">stab-in-the-back legend</a>, which argued that Germany had lost World War I because of those who wanted to overthrow the government. The Weimar government was accused of betraying Germany by signing the Versailles Treaty.
</p><p>By 1932, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Germany" title="Communist Party of Germany">German Communist Party</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Party" title="Nazi Party">Nazi Party</a> controlled the majority of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reichstag_(Weimar_Republic)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reichstag (Weimar Republic) (page does not exist)">Parliament</a>, fuelled by discontent with the Weimar government. After a series of unsuccessful cabinets, President <a href="/wiki/Paul_von_Hindenburg" title="Paul von Hindenburg">Paul von Hindenburg</a> appointed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> as Chancellor of Germany on 30 January 1933.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> On 27 February 1933 the <a href="/wiki/Reichstag_fire" title="Reichstag fire">Reichstag</a> building went up in flames, and a consequent <a href="/wiki/Reichstag_Fire_Decree" title="Reichstag Fire Decree">emergency decree</a> abrogated basic citizens' rights. An <a href="/wiki/Enabling_act" title="Enabling act">enabling act</a> passed in parliament gave Hitler unrestricted legislative power. Only the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">Social Democratic Party</a> voted against it, while <a href="/wiki/KPD" title="KPD" class="mw-redirect">Communist</a> <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament" title="Member of Parliament">MPs</a> had already been imprisoned.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> Using his powers to crush any actual or potential resistance, Hitler established a centralised <a href="/w/index.php?title=Totalitarian_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Totalitarian state (page does not exist)">totalitarian state</a> within months. Industry was revitalised with a focus on military rearmament.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1935, Germany reacquired control of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saar_(League_of_Nations)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saar (League of Nations) (page does not exist)">Saar</a> and in 1936 military control of the <a href="/wiki/Rhineland" title="Rhineland">Rhineland</a>, both of which had been lost in the Treaty of Versailles.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> In 1938, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a> was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anschluss&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anschluss (page does not exist)">annexed</a>, and in 1939, <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Czechoslovakia" title="German occupation of Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> was brought under German control. The <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invasion of Poland</a> was prepared through the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_pact&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop pact (page does not exist)">Molotov–Ribbentrop pact</a> and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Himmler" title="Operation Himmler">Operation Himmler</a>. On 1 September 1939 the German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wehrmacht&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wehrmacht (page does not exist)">Wehrmacht</a> launched a <a href="/wiki/Blitzkrieg" title="Blitzkrieg">blitzkrieg</a> on <a href="/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic" title="Second Polish Republic">Poland</a>, which was swiftly occupied by Germany and by the Soviet <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a>. The UK and France declared war on Germany, marking the beginning of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fulbrook_190_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fulbrook_190-39">[39]</a></sup> As the war progressed, Germany and its <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">allies</a> quickly gained control of most of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Occupied_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Occupied Europe (page does not exist)">continental Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, though plans to <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">force the United Kingdom</a> to an armistice or surrender failed. On 22 June 1941, Germany broke the Molotov–Ribbentrop pact and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a>. <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> led Germany to declare war on the United States. The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a> forced the German army to retreat on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern front</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fulbrook_190_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fulbrook_190-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fotothek_df_pk_0000180_001.jpg" title="File:Fotothek df pk 0000180 001.jpg">File:Fotothek df pk 0000180 001.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Berlin in ruins after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a></div></div></div>In September 1943, Germany's ally Italy surrendered, and German troops were forced to defend an additional front in Italy. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Normandy_Landings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Normandy Landings (page does not exist)">D-Day</a> opened a <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Western Front (World War II)">Western front</a>, as Allied forces advanced towards German territory. On 8 May 1945, <a href="/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day" title="Victory in Europe Day">the German armed forces surrendered</a> after the Red Army occupied Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
<p>In what later became known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Holocaust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Holocaust (page does not exist)">The Holocaust</a>, the Third Reich regime had enacted policies directly subjugating many dissidents and minorities. Millions of people were murdered by the Nazis during the Holocaust, including several million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jews&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jews (page does not exist)">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porajmos" title="Porajmos">Romani people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Generalplan_Ost" title="Generalplan Ost">Slavic people</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazi_crimes_against_Soviet_POWs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nazi crimes against Soviet POWs (page does not exist)">Soviet POWs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Action_T4" title="Action T4">people with mental and/or physical disabilities</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_homosexuals_in_Nazi_Germany_and_the_Holocaust" title="Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust">homosexuals</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Holocaust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Holocaust (page does not exist)">members of the political and religious opposition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> World War II was responsible for <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">more than 40&#160;million dead in Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_casualties_in_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German casualties in World War II (page does not exist)">war casualties for Germany</a> are estimated at 5.3 million German soldiers,<sup id="cite_ref-R.C5.B1diger_Overmans_2000_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-R.C5.B1diger_Overmans_2000-43">[43]</a></sup> millions of <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_casualties_in_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German casualties in World War II (page does not exist)">German civilians</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> and losing the war resulted in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oder-Neisse_line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oder-Neisse line (page does not exist)">large territorial losses</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expulsion_of_Germans_after_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expulsion of Germans after World War II (page does not exist)">the expulsion of about 15&#160;million ethnic Germans</a> from <a href="/wiki/Former_eastern_territories_of_Germany" title="Former eastern territories of Germany">former eastern territories of Germany</a> and other formerly occupied <a href="/w/index.php?title=Flight_and_expulsion_of_Germans_(1944%E2%80%931950)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flight and expulsion of Germans (1944–1950) (page does not exist)">European countries</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rape_during_the_occupation_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rape during the occupation of Germany (page does not exist)">mass rape of German women</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Strategic_bombing_during_World_War_II" title="Strategic bombing during World War II">destruction of numerous major cities</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Nuremberg_trials" title="Nuremberg trials" class="mw-redirect">Nuremberg trials</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazi_war_criminals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nazi war criminals (page does not exist)">Nazi war criminals</a> were held after World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="East_and_West_Germany">East and West Germany</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map-Germany-1945.svg" title="File:Map-Germany-1945.svg">File:Map-Germany-1945.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Allied_Occupation_Zones_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allied Occupation Zones in Germany (page does not exist)">Occupation zones</a> in Germany, 1947. The territories east of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oder-Neisse_line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oder-Neisse line (page does not exist)">Oder-Neisse line</a>, under Polish and Soviet <i>de jure</i> administration and <i>de facto</i> annexation, are shown as white as is the detached <a href="/wiki/Saar_(protectorate)" title="Saar (protectorate)">Saar protectorate</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the surrender of Germany, the remaining German territory and Berlin were partitioned by the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> into four military occupation zones. Together, these zones accepted more than 6.5 million of the ethnic Germans expelled from eastern areas.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> The western sectors, controlled by France, the United Kingdom, and the United States, were merged on 23 May 1949 to form the <i><a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a></i> (<i>Bundesrepublik Deutschland</i>); on 7 October 1949, the Soviet Zone became the <i><a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">German Democratic Republic</a></i> (<i>Deutsche Demokratische Republik</i>, or DDR). They were informally known as "West Germany" and "East Germany". East Germany selected East Berlin as its capital, while West Germany chose <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a> as a provisional capital,  to emphasise its stance that the two-state solution was an artificial and temporary <i>status quo</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> 
</p><p>West Germany, established as a federal parliamentary republic with a "<a href="/wiki/Social_market_economy" title="Social market economy">social market economy</a>", was allied with the United States, the UK and France. <a href="/wiki/Konrad_Adenauer" title="Konrad Adenauer">Konrad Adenauer</a> was elected the first <a href="/wiki/Federal_Chancellor_of_the_Federal_Republic_of_Germany" title="Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany">Federal Chancellor</a> (<i>Bundeskanzler</i>) of Germany in 1949 and remained in office until 1963. Under his and <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_Erhard" title="Ludwig Erhard">Ludwig Erhard</a>'s leadership, the country enjoyed prolonged economic growth beginning in the early 1950s, that became famous as the "economic miracle" (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-de&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-de (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-de</a>). West Germany joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 1955 and was a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> in 1957.
</p><p>East Germany was an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> state under political and military control by the <a href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR" class="mw-redirect">USSR</a> via the latter's occupation forces and the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>. Though East Germany claimed to be a democracy, political power was exercised solely by leading members (<i><a href="/wiki/Politburo" title="Politburo">Politbüro</a></i>) of the communist-controlled <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Unity_Party_of_Germany" title="Socialist Unity Party of Germany">Socialist Unity Party of Germany</a> (SED), supported by the <a href="/wiki/Stasi" title="Stasi">Stasi</a>, an immense secret service,<sup id="cite_ref-spiegel_20080311_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-spiegel_20080311-50">[50]</a></sup> and a variety of sub-organisations controlling every aspect of society. A Soviet-style <a href="/wiki/Command_economy" title="Command economy" class="mw-redirect">command economy</a> was set up; the GDR later became a <a href="/wiki/Comecon" title="Comecon">Comecon</a> state.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG" title="File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG">File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> in front of the <a href="/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate" title="Brandenburg Gate">Brandenburg Gate</a> shortly before its fall in 1989. Today the Gate is often regarded as Germany's main national <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landmark&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landmark (page does not exist)">landmark</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>While <a href="/w/index.php?title=Communist_propaganda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Communist propaganda (page does not exist)">East German propaganda</a> was based on the benefits of the GDR's social programmes and the alleged constant threat of a West German invasion, many of its citizens looked to the West for freedom and prosperity.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT_19890822_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_19890822-52">[52]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a>, built in 1961 to stop East Germans from escaping to West Germany, became a symbol of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup> hence its fall in 1989, following democratic reforms in Poland and Hungary, became a symbol of the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Communism" title="Fall of Communism" class="mw-redirect">Fall of Communism</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Reunification" title="German Reunification" class="mw-redirect">German Reunification</a> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Die_Wende&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Die Wende (page does not exist)">Die Wende</a></i>.
</p><p>Tensions between East and West Germany were reduced in the early 1970s by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chancellor_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chancellor of Germany (page does not exist)">Chancellor</a> <a href="/wiki/Willy_Brandt" title="Willy Brandt">Willy Brandt</a>'s <span lang="de"><i><a href="/wiki/Ostpolitik" title="Ostpolitik">Ostpolitik</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>. In summer 1989, Hungary decided to dismantle the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_Curtain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron Curtain (page does not exist)">Iron Curtain</a> and open the borders, causing the emigration of thousands of <a href="/wiki/East_Germans" title="East Germans" class="mw-redirect">East Germans</a> to West Germany via Hungary. This had devastating effects on the <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">GDR</a>, where regular <a href="/w/index.php?title=Monday_demonstrations_in_East_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monday demonstrations in East Germany (page does not exist)">mass demonstrations</a> received increasing support. The East German authorities unexpectedly eased the border restrictions, allowing East German citizens to travel to the West; originally intended to help retain East Germany as a state, the opening of the border actually led to an acceleration of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Die_Wende&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Die Wende (page does not exist)"><i>Wende</i> reform process</a>. This culminated in the <i><a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Final_Settlement_with_Respect_to_Germany" title="Treaty on the Final Settlement with Respect to Germany">Two Plus Four Treaty</a></i> a year later on 12 September 1990, under which the four occupying powers renounced their rights under the <a href="/wiki/German_Instrument_of_Surrender" title="German Instrument of Surrender">Instrument of Surrender</a>, and Germany regained full sovereignty. This permitted <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">German reunification</a> on 3 October 1990, with the accession of the five re-established states of the former GDR (<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_states_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New states of Germany (page does not exist)">new states</a> or "neue Länder").<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="German_Reunification_and_the_EU">German Reunification and the EU</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Berlin_reichstag_CP.jpg" title="File:Berlin reichstag CP.jpg">File:Berlin reichstag CP.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <i>German Unity Flag</i> is a national memorial to <a href="/wiki/German_Reunification" title="German Reunification" class="mw-redirect">German Reunification</a> that was raised on 3 October 1990. It waves in front of the <a href="/wiki/Reichstag_building" title="Reichstag building">Bundestag</a> in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> (seat of the <a href="/wiki/German_parliament" title="German parliament" class="mw-redirect">German parliament</a>).</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Based on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlin/Bonn_Act&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlin/Bonn Act (page does not exist)">Berlin/Bonn Act</a>, adopted on 10 March 1994, <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> once again became the capital of the reunified Germany, while <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a> obtained the unique status of a <i>Bundesstadt</i> (federal city) retaining some federal ministries.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> The relocation of the government was completed in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since reunification, Germany has taken a more active role in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and NATO. Germany sent a peacekeeping force to secure stability in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=1999_NATO_bombing_in_Yugoslavia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="1999 NATO bombing in Yugoslavia (page does not exist)">Balkans</a> and sent a force of <a href="/wiki/Bundeswehr" title="Bundeswehr">German troops</a> to <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a> as part of a NATO effort to provide <a href="/w/index.php?title=War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present) (page does not exist)">security in that country</a> after the ousting of the <a href="/wiki/Taliban" title="Taliban">Taliban</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> These deployments were controversial since, after the war, Germany was bound by domestic law only to deploy troops for defence roles.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> became the first female Chancellor of Germany as the leader of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Grand_coalition_(Germany)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Grand coalition (Germany) (page does not exist)">grand coalition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup> Germany hosted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=33rd_G8_summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="33rd G8 summit (page does not exist)">2007 G8 summit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Heiligendamm" title="Heiligendamm">Heiligendamm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mecklenburg" title="Mecklenburg">Mecklenburg</a>. In 2009, a <a href="/wiki/Free_Democratic_Party_(Germany)" title="Free Democratic Party (Germany)">liberal</a>-<a href="/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_(Germany)" title="Christian Democratic Union (Germany)">conservative</a> coalition under <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Merkel</a> assumed leadership of the country.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Deutschland_topo.jpg" title="File:Deutschland topo.jpg">File:Deutschland topo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Topographic map</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Germany is in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Denmark" title="Denmark">Denmark</a> bordering to the north, <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> to the east, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> to the south, <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a> to the southwest, and <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> to the northwest. It lies mostly between latitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=47th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="47th parallel north (page does not exist)">47°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=55th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="55th parallel north (page does not exist)">55° N</a> (the tip of <a href="/wiki/Sylt" title="Sylt">Sylt</a> is just north of 55°), and longitudes <a href="/w/index.php?title=5th_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="5th meridian east (page does not exist)">5°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=16th_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="16th meridian east (page does not exist)">16° E</a>. The territory covers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, consisting of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of land and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of water. It is the seventh largest country by area in Europe and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by area (page does not exist)">62nd largest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Elevation ranges from the mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a> (highest point: the <a href="/wiki/Zugspitze" title="Zugspitze">Zugspitze</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>) in the south to the shores of the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> (<i>Nordsee</i>) in the northwest and the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> (<i>Ostsee</i>) in the northeast. The forested uplands of central Germany and the lowlands of northern Germany (lowest point: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wilstermarsch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wilstermarsch (page does not exist)">Wilstermarsch</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> below sea level) are traversed by such major rivers as the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danube&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danube (page does not exist)">Danube</a> and <a href="/wiki/Elbe" title="Elbe">Elbe</a>.  Glaciers are found in the Alpine region, but are experiencing deglaciation. Significant natural resources are iron ore, coal, <a href="/wiki/Potash" title="Potash">potash</a>, timber, <a href="/wiki/Lignite" title="Lignite">lignite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, copper, natural gas, salt, nickel, <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a> and water.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Steilk%C3%BCste_bei_Ahrenshoop.jpg" title="File:Steilküste bei Ahrenshoop.jpg">File:Steilküste bei Ahrenshoop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Typical coastal landscape in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Germany (page does not exist)">Northern Germany</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steep_coast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steep coast (page does not exist)">Steep coast</a> at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fischland-Darss-Zingst&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fischland-Darss-Zingst (page does not exist)">Darss</a> <i>West Beach</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_Pomerania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western Pomerania (page does not exist)">Western Pomerania</a>).</div></div></div>
<p>Most of Germany has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temperate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temperate (page does not exist)">temperate seasonal climate</a> in which humid westerly winds predominate. The country is situated in between the <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a> Western European and the <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental</a> Eastern European climate. The climate is moderated by the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Current" title="North Atlantic Current">North Atlantic Drift</a>, the northern extension of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a>. This warmer water affects the areas bordering the North Sea; consequently in the northwest and the north the climate is <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic</a>. Germany gets an average of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Precipitation_(meteorology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Precipitation (meteorology) (page does not exist)">precipitation</a> per year. Rainfall occurs year-round, with no obligatory dry season. Winters are mild and summers tend to be warm, temperatures can exceed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>The east has a more <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a>; winters can be very cold and summers very warm, and longer dry periods can occur. Central and southern Germany are transition regions which vary from moderately oceanic to continental. In addition to the maritime and continental climates that predominate over most of the country, the Alpine regions in the extreme south and, to a lesser degree, some areas of the Central German Uplands have a mountain climate, characterised by lower temperatures and greater precipitation.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Golden_Eagle_in_flight_-_5.jpg" title="File:Golden Eagle in flight - 5.jpg">File:Golden Eagle in flight - 5.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Golden_Eagle" title="Golden Eagle">Golden Eagle</a> is a protected bird of prey.</div></div></div>
<p>The territory of Germany can be subdivided into two <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregions</a>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=European-Mediterranean_montane_mixed_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European-Mediterranean montane mixed forests (page does not exist)">European-Mediterranean montane mixed forests</a> and Northeast-Atlantic shelf marine.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> the majority of Germany is covered by either arable land (34%) or forest and <a href="/wiki/Woodland" title="Woodland">woodland</a> (30.1%); only 13.4% of the area consists of permanent pastures, 11.8% is covered by settlements and streets.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>Plants and animals are those generally common to middle Europe. Beeches, oaks, and other deciduous trees constitute one-third of the forests; conifers are increasing as a result of reforestation. Spruce and fir trees predominate in the upper mountains, while pine and larch are found in sandy soil. There are many species of ferns, flowers, fungi, and mosses. Wild animals include deer, wild boar, mouflon, fox, badger, hare, and small numbers of beavers.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prussian_blue" title="Prussian blue">blue</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cornflower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cornflower (page does not exist)">cornflower</a> was once a German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Floral_emblem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Floral emblem (page does not exist)">national symbol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 14 <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Germany" title="List of national parks of Germany">national parks in Germany</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Jasmund_National_Park" title="Jasmund National Park">Jasmund National Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Vorpommern_Lagoon_Area_National_Park" title="Vorpommern Lagoon Area National Park" class="mw-redirect">Vorpommern Lagoon Area National Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCritz_National_Park" title="Müritz National Park">Müritz National Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Wadden_Sea_National_Parks" title="Wadden Sea National Parks">Wadden Sea National Parks</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Harz_National_Park" title="Harz National Park">Harz National Park</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hainich_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hainich National Park (page does not exist)">Hainich National Park</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saxon_Switzerland_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saxon Switzerland National Park (page does not exist)">Saxon Switzerland National Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bavarian_Forest_National_Park" title="Bavarian Forest National Park">Bavarian Forest National Park</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berchtesgaden_National_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berchtesgaden National Park (page does not exist)">Berchtesgaden National Park</a>. In addition, there are  14 <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves_in_Europe_and_North_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves in Europe and North America (page does not exist)">Biosphere Reserves</a>, as well as 98 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nature_parks_(Germany)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nature parks (Germany) (page does not exist)">nature parks</a>.
</p><p>More than 400 registered zoos and animal parks operate in Germany, which is believed to be the largest number in any country.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Zoological_Garden" title="Berlin Zoological Garden">Berlin Zoo</a> opened in 1844 is the oldest zoo in Germany, and presents the most comprehensive collection of species in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Political_System_of_Germany.svg" title="File:Political System of Germany.svg">File:Political System of Germany.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Germany" title="Politics of Germany">Political system of Germany</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Reichstag_building_Berlin_view_from_west_before_sunset.jpg" title="File:Reichstag building Berlin view from west before sunset.jpg">File:Reichstag building Berlin view from west before sunset.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reichstag_(building)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reichstag (building) (page does not exist)">Reichstag building</a> in Berlin is the site of the German parliament (<a href="/wiki/Bundestag" title="Bundestag">Bundestag</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Germany is a <a href="/wiki/Federal_republic" title="Federal republic">federal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parliamentary_democratic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parliamentary democratic (page does not exist)">parliamentary</a>, <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democratic</a> republic. The German political system operates under a framework laid out in the 1949 constitutional document known as the <i><a href="/wiki/Basic_Law_for_the_Federal_Republic_of_Germany" title="Basic Law for the Federal Republic of Germany">Grundgesetz</a></i> (Basic Law). Amendments generally require a two-thirds majority of both chambers of parliament; the fundamental principles of the constitution, as expressed in the articles guaranteeing human dignity, the separation of powers, the federal structure, and the rule of law are valid in perpetuity.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Germany" title="President of Germany">president</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and invested primarily with representative responsibilities and powers. He is elected by the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Bundesversammlung_(Germany)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bundesversammlung (Germany) (page does not exist)">Bundesversammlung</a></i> (federal convention), an institution consisting of the members of the <i>Bundestag</i> and an equal number of state delegates. The second-highest official in the <a href="/wiki/German_order_of_precedence" title="German order of precedence">German order of precedence</a> is the <i>Bundestagspräsident</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=President_of_the_Bundestag&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President of the Bundestag (page does not exist)">President of the <i>Bundestag</i></a>), who is elected by the <i>Bundestag</i> and responsible for overseeing the daily sessions of the body.
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:left; margin-right:9px; margin-left:2px;">

<tr>
<td align="left"> <a href="/wiki/File:2011_Joachim_Gauck-2.jpg" title="File:2011 Joachim Gauck-2.jpg">111px</a> </td>
<td align="left"> <a href="/wiki/File:Angela_Merkel_(August_2012)_cropped.jpg" title="File:Angela Merkel (August 2012) cropped.jpg">125px</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
