<td align="center"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Joachim_Gauck&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joachim Gauck (page does not exist)">Joachim Gauck</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Germany" title="President of Germany">President</a> since 2012</small>
</td>
<td align="center"><a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a><br /><small><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chancellor_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chancellor of Germany (page does not exist)">Chancellor</a> since 2005</small>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The third-highest official and the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chancellor_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chancellor of Germany (page does not exist)">Chancellor</a>, who is appointed by the <i>Bundespräsident</i> after being elected by the <i>Bundestag</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup> The chancellor, currently <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a>, is the head of government and exercises <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive power</a>, similar to the role of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prime_Minister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prime Minister (page does not exist)">Prime Minister</a> in other parliamentary democracies.
</p><p>Federal <a href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power" class="mw-redirect">legislative power</a> is vested in the parliament consisting of the <i><a href="/wiki/Bundestag" title="Bundestag">Bundestag</a></i> (Federal Diet) and <i><a href="/wiki/Bundesrat_of_Germany" title="Bundesrat of Germany">Bundesrat</a></i> (Federal Council), which together form the legislative body. The <i>Bundestag</i> is elected through <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">direct elections</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportional representation</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mixed_member_proportional_representation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mixed member proportional representation (page does not exist)">mixed-member</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup> The members of the <i>Bundesrat</i> represent the governments of the sixteen federated states and are members of the state cabinets.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1949, the party system has been dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Christian_Democratic_Union_(Germany)" title="Christian Democratic Union (Germany)">Christian Democratic Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Germany" title="Social Democratic Party of Germany">Social Democratic Party of Germany</a>. So far every chancellor has been a member of one of these parties. However, the smaller liberal <a href="/wiki/Free_Democratic_Party_(Germany)" title="Free Democratic Party (Germany)">Free Democratic Party</a> (which had members in the Bundestag from 1949 to 2013) and the <a href="/wiki/Alliance_%2790/The_Greens" title="Alliance '90/The Greens">Alliance '90/The Greens</a> (which has had seats in parliament since 1983) have also played important roles.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Germany" title="List of political parties in Germany">Minor parties</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Left_(Germany)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Left (Germany) (page does not exist)">The Left</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_Voters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free Voters (page does not exist)">Free Voters</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pirate_Party_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pirate Party Germany (page does not exist)">Pirate Party</a> are represented in some <a href="/wiki/Landtag" title="Landtag">state parliaments</a>.
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law">Law</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Uniformmodell_Hessen4.JPG" title="File:Uniformmodell Hessen4.JPG">File:Uniformmodell Hessen4.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landespolizei&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landespolizei (page does not exist)">State Police</a>, typical officer uniforms and car colours</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Germany has a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law system</a> based on <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">Roman law</a> with some references to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germanic_law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germanic law (page does not exist)">Germanic law</a>. The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Federal_Constitutional_Court_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Federal Constitutional Court of Germany (page does not exist)">Bundesverfassungsgericht</a></i> (Federal Constitutional Court) is the German Supreme Court responsible for constitutional matters, with power of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Judicial_review&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Judicial review (page does not exist)">judicial review</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> Germany's supreme court system, called <i>Oberste Gerichtshöfe des Bundes</i>, is specialised: for civil and criminal cases, the highest court of appeal is the <a href="/wiki/Inquisitorial_system" title="Inquisitorial system">inquisitorial</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_Court_of_Justice_of_Germany" title="Federal Court of Justice of Germany">Federal Court of Justice</a>, and for other affairs the courts are the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Federal_Labor_Court_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Federal Labor Court of Germany (page does not exist)">Federal Labour Court</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bundessozialgericht" title="Bundessozialgericht" class="mw-redirect">Federal Social Court</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Finance_Court_of_Germany" title="Federal Finance Court of Germany">Federal Finance Court</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Administrative_Court_of_Germany" title="Federal Administrative Court of Germany">Federal Administrative Court</a>.  The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=V%C3%B6lkerstrafgesetzbuch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Völkerstrafgesetzbuch (page does not exist)">Völkerstrafgesetzbuch</a></i> regulates the consequences of <a href="/wiki/Crimes_against_humanity" title="Crimes against humanity">crimes against humanity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genocide" title="Genocide">genocide</a> and <a href="/wiki/War_crimes" title="War crimes" class="mw-redirect">war crimes</a>, and gives German courts <a href="/wiki/Universal_jurisdiction" title="Universal jurisdiction">universal jurisdiction</a> in some circumstances.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Criminal and private laws are codified on the national level in the <i><a href="/wiki/Strafgesetzbuch" title="Strafgesetzbuch">Strafgesetzbuch</a></i> and the <i><a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCrgerliches_Gesetzbuch" title="Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch">Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch</a></i> respectively. The German penal system is aimed towards rehabilitation of the criminal and the protection of the general public.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Except for petty crimes, which are tried before a single professional judge, and serious <a href="/wiki/Political_crime" title="Political crime">political crimes</a>, all charges are tried before mixed tribunals on which <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lay_judge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lay judge (page does not exist)">lay judges</a> (<i><span lang="de"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sch%C3%B6ffe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schöffe (page does not exist)">Schöffen</a></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a></i>) sit side by side with professional judges.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of the fundamental matters of <a href="/wiki/Administrative_law" title="Administrative law">administrative law</a> remain in the jurisdiction of the states, though most states base their own laws in that area on the 1976 <i>Verwaltungsverfahrensgesetz</i> (Administrative Proceedings Act) covering important points of administrative law. The <i>Oberverwaltungsgerichte</i> are the highest level of administrative jurisdiction concerning the state administrations, unless the question of law concerns federal law or state law identical to federal law. In such cases, final appeal to the Federal Administrative Court is possible.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constituent_states">Constituent states</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Germany comprises sixteen states which are collectively referred to as <i>Länder</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
Each state has its own state constitution<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> and is largely autonomous in regard to its internal organisation. Because of differences in size and population the <a href="/wiki/States_of_Germany#Subdivisions" title="States of Germany">subdivisions of these states</a> vary, especially as between <a href="/wiki/City_states" title="City states" class="mw-redirect">city states</a> (<i>Stadtstaaten</i>) and states with larger territories (<i>Flächenländer</i>). For regional administrative purposes five states, namely Baden-Württemberg, Bavaria, Hesse, North Rhine-Westphalia and Saxony, consist of a total of 22 <a href="/wiki/Regierungsbezirke" title="Regierungsbezirke" class="mw-redirect">Government Districts</a> (<i>Regierungsbezirke</i>). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> Germany is divided into 403 <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Germany" title="Districts of Germany">districts</a> (<i>Kreise</i>) at a municipal level; these consist of 301 <a href="/wiki/List_of_rural_districts_of_Germany" title="List of rural districts of Germany" class="mw-redirect">rural districts</a> and 102 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Urban_districts_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Urban districts of Germany (page does not exist)">urban districts</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:German_Federal_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:German Federal States (page does not exist)">Template:German Federal States</a>
</p>
<table style="background:none;" cellspacing="2px">
<tr>
<td>
<table class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:left; font-size:90%;">

<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Brandenburg" title="Brandenburg">Brandenburg</a> </td>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Potsdam" title="Potsdam">Potsdam</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:right">29,477</td>
<td style="text-align:right">2,449,500
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Bremen_(state)" title="Bremen (state)">Bremen</a> </td>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bremen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bremen (page does not exist)">Bremen</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:right">404</td>
<td style="text-align:right">654,800
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td style="text-align:right">755</td>
<td style="text-align:right">1,734,300
</td></tr>

</td></tr></table>
</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:33rdG8Leaders.jpg" title="File:33rdG8Leaders.jpg">File:33rdG8Leaders.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chancellor <a href="/wiki/Angela_Merkel" title="Angela Merkel">Angela Merkel</a> hosting the <a href="/wiki/G8" title="G8">G8</a> summit in <a href="/wiki/Heiligendamm" title="Heiligendamm">Heiligendamm</a></div></div></div>
<p>Germany has a network of 229 diplomatic missions abroad<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> and maintains relations with more than 190 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> it is the largest contributor to the budget of the European Union (providing 20%)<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> and the third largest contributor to the UN (providing 8%).<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Germany is a member of NATO, the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), the G8, the G20, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). It has played a leading role in the European Union since its inception and has maintained a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Franco-German_cooperation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Franco-German cooperation (page does not exist)">strong alliance with France</a> since the end of World War II. Germany seeks to advance the creation of a more unified European political, defence, and security apparatus.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>The development policy of the Federal Republic of Germany is an independent area of German foreign policy. It is formulated by the Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) and carried out by the implementing organisations. The German government sees development policy as a joint responsibility of the international community.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> It is the world's third biggest aid donor after the United States and France.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Cold War, Germany's partition by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_Curtain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron Curtain (page does not exist)">Iron Curtain</a> made it a symbol of East–West tensions and a political battleground in Europe. However, Willy Brandt's Ostpolitik was a key factor in the <i><a href="/wiki/D%C3%A9tente" title="Détente">détente</a></i> of the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> In 1999, Chancellor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gerhard_Schr%C3%B6der&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gerhard Schröder (page does not exist)">Gerhard Schröder</a>'s government defined a new basis for German foreign policy by taking part in the NATO decisions surrounding the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a> and by sending German troops into combat for the first time since World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> The governments of Germany and the United States are close political allies.<sup id="cite_ref-state_27-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-state-27">[27]</a></sup> The 1948 <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a> and strong cultural ties have crafted a strong bond between the two countries, although Schröder's vocal opposition to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iraq_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iraq War (page does not exist)">Iraq War</a> suggested the end of <a href="/wiki/Atlanticism" title="Atlanticism">Atlanticism</a> and a relative cooling of German-American relations.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> The two countries are also economically interdependent: 8.8% of German exports are US-bound and 6.6% of German imports originate from the US.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eurofighter_9803.ogg" title="File:Eurofighter 9803.ogg">File:Eurofighter 9803.ogg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Eurofighter_Typhoon" title="Eurofighter Typhoon">Eurofighter Typhoon</a> is part of the <a href="/wiki/German_Air_Force" title="German Air Force">Luftwaffe</a></div></div></div>
<p>Germany's military, the <i>Bundeswehr</i>, is organised into <i><a href="/wiki/German_Army" title="German Army">Heer</a></i> (Army), <i><a href="/wiki/German_Navy" title="German Navy">Marine</a></i> (Navy), <i><a href="/wiki/German_Air_Force" title="German Air Force">Luftwaffe</a></i> (Air Force), <i><a href="/wiki/Bundeswehr_Joint_Medical_Service" title="Bundeswehr Joint Medical Service">Bundeswehr Joint Medical Service</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Streitkr%C3%A4ftebasis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Streitkräftebasis (page does not exist)">Streitkräftebasis</a></i> (Joint Support Service) branches. The role of the <i>Bundeswehr</i> is described in the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Germany" title="Constitution of Germany" class="mw-redirect">Constitution of Germany</a> (Art. 87a) as absolutely defensive only. Its only active role before 1990 was the <i>Katastropheneinsatz</i> (disaster control). Within the <i>Bundeswehr</i>, it helped after natural disasters both in Germany and abroad. After 1990, the international situation changed from East-West confrontation to one of general uncertainty and instability. Today, after a ruling of the Federal Constitutional Court in 1994 the term "defense" has been defined to not only include protection of the borders of Germany, but also crisis reaction and conflict prevention, or more broadly as guarding the <a href="/wiki/Security" title="Security">security</a> of Germany anywhere in the world.  
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leopard_2_A5_der_Bundeswehr.jpg" title="File:Leopard 2 A5 der Bundeswehr.jpg">File:Leopard 2 A5 der Bundeswehr.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Leopard_2" title="Leopard 2">Leopard 2</a> tanks of the <a href="/wiki/German_Army" title="German Army">German Army</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, military spending was an estimated 1.3% of the country's GDP, which is low in a ranking of all countries; in absolute terms, German military expenditure is the 9th highest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> In peacetime, the Bundeswehr is commanded by the Minister of Defence. If Germany went to war, which according to the constitution is allowed only for defensive purposes, the Chancellor would become commander-in-chief of the <i>Bundeswehr</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> the Bundeswehr employs 183,000 professional soldiers and 17,000 volunteers.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> The German government plans to reduce the number of soldiers to 170,000 professionals and up to 15,000 short-term volunteers (<i>voluntary military service</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-bwzukunft_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bwzukunft-92">[92]</a></sup> Reservists are available to the Armed Forces and participate in defence exercises and deployments abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-bwzukunft_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bwzukunft-92">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the German military had about 6,900 troops stationed in foreign countries as part of international peacekeeping forces, including about 4,900 Bundeswehr troops in the NATO-led <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">ISAF</a> force in Afghanistan and <a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, 1,150 German soldiers in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, and 300 troops with <a href="/wiki/UNIFIL" title="UNIFIL" class="mw-redirect">UNIFIL</a> in Lebanon.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until 2011, <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_Germany" title="Conscription in Germany">military service</a> was compulsory for men at age 18, and conscripts served six-month tours of duty; conscientious objectors could instead opt for an equal length of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Zivildienst&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Zivildienst (page does not exist)">Zivildienst</a></i> (civilian service), or a six-year commitment to (voluntary) emergency services like a <a href="/wiki/Volunteer_fire_department" title="Volunteer fire department">fire department</a> or the <a href="/wiki/German_Red_Cross" title="German Red Cross">Red Cross</a>. On 1 July 2011 conscription was officially suspended and replaced with a voluntary service.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> Since 2001 women may serve in all functions of service without restriction, but they have not been subject to conscription. There are presently some 17,500 women on active duty and a number of female reservists.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Labour_productivity_levels_in_europe.svg" title="File:Labour productivity levels in europe.svg">File:Labour productivity levels in europe.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Workforce_productivity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Workforce productivity (page does not exist)">labour productivity</a> level of Germany is one of the highest in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>. <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD" class="mw-redirect">OECD</a>, 2012</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mercedes_Benz_AMG_SLS_Black.jpg" title="File:Mercedes Benz AMG SLS Black.jpg">File:Mercedes Benz AMG SLS Black.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-Benz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mercedes-Benz (page does not exist)">Mercedes-Benz</a> car. Germany was the world's leading exporter of goods from 2003 to 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Eurozone.svg" title="File:Eurozone.svg">File:Eurozone.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Germany is part of a monetary union, the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">eurozone</a> (dark blue), and of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Internal_Market_(European_Union)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Internal Market (European Union) (page does not exist)">EU single market</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Germany has a <a href="/wiki/Social_market_economy" title="Social market economy">social market economy</a> with a highly skilled <a href="/wiki/Labour_force" title="Labour force" class="mw-redirect">labour force</a>, a large <a href="/wiki/Capital_stock" title="Capital stock" class="mw-redirect">capital stock</a>, a low level of corruption,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> and a high level of innovation.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> It has the largest and most powerful national economy in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">fourth largest by nominal GDP</a> in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-wbpdf_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wbpdf-100">[100]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">fifth largest by PPP</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> and was the biggest net contributor to the EU budget in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tertiary_sector_of_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tertiary sector of industry (page does not exist)">service sector</a> contributes approximately 71% of the total GDP, industry 28%, and agriculture 1%.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup> The official average national unemployment rate in June 2013 was 6.6%.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> However, the official average national unemployment rate also includes people with a part-time job that are looking for a full-time job.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> The unofficial average national unemployment rate in 2011 was 5.7%.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germany is an advocate of closer European economic and political integration. Its commercial policies are increasingly determined by agreements among European Union (EU) members and by EU legislation. Germany introduced the common European currency, the euro, on 1 January 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-euroc_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euroc-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Its monetary policy is set by the <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">European Central Bank</a>, which is headquartered in Frankfurt. Two decades after <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">German reunification</a>, <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">standards of living</a> and per capita incomes remain significantly higher in the states of the former West Germany than in the former East.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> The modernisation and integration of the eastern German economy is a long-term process scheduled to last until the year 2019, with annual transfers from west to east amounting to roughly $80&#160;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> In January 2009 the German government approved a €50&#160;billion economic stimulus plan to protect several sectors from a downturn and a subsequent rise in unemployment rates.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Of the world's 500 largest stock-market-listed companies measured by revenue in 2010, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fortune_Global_500&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fortune Global 500 (page does not exist)">Fortune Global 500</a>, 37 are headquartered in Germany. 30 Germany-based companies are included in the <a href="/wiki/DAX" title="DAX">DAX</a>, the German stock market index. Well-known global brands are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-Benz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mercedes-Benz (page does not exist)">Mercedes-Benz</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/SAP_AG" title="SAP AG">SAP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adidas" title="Adidas">Adidas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">Audi</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Allianz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allianz (page does not exist)">Allianz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Porsche" title="Porsche">Porsche</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bayer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bayer (page does not exist)">Bayer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Bosch_GmbH" title="Robert Bosch GmbH">Bosch</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nivea" title="Nivea">Nivea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> Germany is recognised for its specialised <a href="/wiki/Small_and_medium_enterprises" title="Small and medium enterprises">small and medium enterprises</a>. Around 1,000 of these companies are global market leaders in their segment and are labelled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hidden_Champions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hidden Champions (page does not exist)">hidden champions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>The list includes the largest German companies by revenue in 2011:
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right;">

<tr style="background:#efefef;">

<th style="text-align:center;"> Revenue<br />(Mil.&#160;€) </th>
<th style="text-align:center;"> Profit<br />(Mil.&#160;€) </th>
<th style="text-align:center;"> Employees<br />(World)
</th></tr>

<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCnchen" title="München" class="mw-redirect">München</a> </td>
<td> 74,000 </td>

<td> 360,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>5. </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/BASF" title="BASF">BASF SE</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ludwigshafen_am_Rhein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ludwigshafen am Rhein (page does not exist)">Ludwigshafen am Rhein</a> </td>
<td> 73,000 </td>
<td> 6,600 </td>
<td> 111,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>6. </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW AG</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/M%C3%BCnchen" title="München" class="mw-redirect">München</a> </td>
<td> 69,000 </td>
<td> 4,900 </td>
<td> 100,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>7. </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Metro_AG" title="Metro AG">Metro AG</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/D%C3%BCsseldorf" title="Düsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a> </td>
<td> 67,000 </td>
<td> 740 </td>
<td> 288,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>8. </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schwarz-Gruppe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schwarz-Gruppe (page does not exist)">Schwarz-Gruppe</a> <sub>(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lidl&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lidl (page does not exist)">Lidl</a>/<a href="/w/index.php?title=Kaufland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kaufland (page does not exist)">Kaufland</a>)</sub> </td>

<td> 63,000 </td>
<td> N/A </td>
<td> 315,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>9. </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Telekom" title="Deutsche Telekom">Deutsche Telekom AG</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a> </td>
<td> 59,000 </td>
<td> 670 </td>
<td> 235,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:0 (page does not exist)">Template:0</a>10. </td>

<td> 471,000
</td></tr>
<tr>

<td> 141,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td align="center"> — </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bank" title="Deutsche Bank">Deutsche Bank AG</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frankfurt_am_Main&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frankfurt am Main (page does not exist)">Frankfurt am Main</a> </td>
<td> 2,160,000 </td>
<td> 4,300 </td>
<td> 101,000
</td></tr></table>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ICE_3_Oberhaider-Wald-Tunnel.jpg" title="File:ICE 3 Oberhaider-Wald-Tunnel.jpg">File:ICE 3 Oberhaider-Wald-Tunnel.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=ICE_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ICE 3 (page does not exist)">ICE 3</a> on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cologne%E2%80%93Frankfurt_high-speed_rail_line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cologne–Frankfurt high-speed rail line (page does not exist)">Cologne–Frankfurt high-speed rail line</a></div></div></div>
<p>With its central position in Europe, Germany is a transport hub. This is reflected in its dense and modern transport networks. The motorway (<a href="/wiki/Autobahn" title="Autobahn">Autobahn</a>) network ranks as the third-largest worldwide in length and is known for its lack of a general speed limit.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> Germany has established a polycentric network of <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed trains</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=InterCityExpress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="InterCityExpress (page does not exist)">InterCityExpress</a> or <i>ICE</i> network of the <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Bahn" title="Deutsche Bahn">Deutsche Bahn</a> serves major German cities as well as destinations in neighbouring countries with speeds up to 300&#160;kph (186&#160;mph).<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> The largest German airports are <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Airport" title="Frankfurt Airport">Frankfurt Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Munich_Airport" title="Munich Airport">Munich Airport</a>, both hubs of <a href="/wiki/Lufthansa" title="Lufthansa">Lufthansa</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Air_Berlin" title="Air Berlin">Air Berlin</a> has hubs at <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Tegel_Airport" title="Berlin Tegel Airport">Berlin Tegel</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=D%C3%BCsseldorf_International_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Düsseldorf International Airport (page does not exist)">Düsseldorf</a>. Other major airports include <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Sch%C3%B6nefeld_Airport" title="Berlin Schönefeld Airport">Berlin Schönefeld</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamburg_Airport" title="Hamburg Airport">Hamburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cologne_Bonn_Airport" title="Cologne Bonn Airport">Cologne/Bonn</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leipzig/Halle_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leipzig/Halle Airport (page does not exist)">Leipzig/Halle</a>. Both airports in Berlin will be consolidated at a site adjacent to Berlin Schönefeld, which will become <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Brandenburg_Airport" title="Berlin Brandenburg Airport">Berlin Brandenburg Airport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, Germany was the world's sixth-largest consumer of energy,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> and 60% of its primary energy was imported.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Government policy promotes <a href="/wiki/Energy_conservation" title="Energy conservation">energy conservation</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_energy_commercialisation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable energy commercialisation (page does not exist)">renewable energy commercialisation</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Efficient_energy_use&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Efficient energy use (page does not exist)">Energy efficiency</a> has been improving since the early 1970s; the government aims to meet the country's electricity demands using 40% renewable sources by 2020 and 100% by 2050.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> In 2010, energy sources were: oil (33.7%); coal, including lignite (22.9%); natural gas (21.8%); nuclear (10.8%); hydro-electric and wind power (1.5%); and other renewable sources (7.9%).<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> In 2000, the government and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_power_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear power in Germany (page does not exist)">nuclear power industry</a> agreed to phase out all <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant" title="Nuclear power plant">nuclear power plants</a> by 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
Germany is committed to the <a href="/wiki/Kyoto_protocol" title="Kyoto protocol" class="mw-redirect">Kyoto protocol</a> and several other treaties promoting biodiversity, low emission standards, recycling, and the use of renewable energy, and supports sustainable development at a global level.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> The German government has initiated wide-ranging emission reduction activities and the country's overall emissions are falling.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup>
Nevertheless the country's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_greenhouse_gas_emissions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas emissions</a> were the highest in the EU <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Einstein_1921_by_F_Schmutzer.jpg" title="File:Einstein 1921 by F Schmutzer.jpg">File:Einstein 1921 by F Schmutzer.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a></div></div></div>
<p>Germany's achievements in the sciences have been significant, and <a href="/wiki/Research_and_development" title="Research and development">research and development</a> efforts form an integral part of the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Germany" title="Economy of Germany">economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prize</a> has been awarded to <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_country#Germany" title="List of Nobel laureates by country">104 German laureates</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> For most of the 20th century, German laureates had more awards than those of any other nation, especially in the sciences (<a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry (page does not exist)">chemistry</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">physiology or medicine</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>The work of <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck" title="Max Planck">Max Planck</a> was crucial to the foundation of modern <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Werner_Heisenberg" title="Werner Heisenberg">Werner Heisenberg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Max_Born" title="Max Born">Max Born</a> developed further.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>  They were preceded by such key physicists as <a href="/wiki/Hermann_von_Helmholtz" title="Hermann von Helmholtz">Hermann von Helmholtz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_von_Fraunhofer" title="Joseph von Fraunhofer">Joseph von Fraunhofer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Daniel_Fahrenheit" title="Gabriel Daniel Fahrenheit" class="mw-redirect">Gabriel Daniel Fahrenheit</a>, among others. <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_R%C3%B6ntgen" title="Wilhelm Röntgen">Wilhelm Röntgen</a> discovered <a href="/wiki/X-ray" title="X-ray">X-rays</a> and was the first winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Otto_Hahn" title="Otto Hahn">Otto Hahn</a> was a pioneer in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Radioactivity" title="Radioactivity" class="mw-redirect">radioactivity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radiochemistry" title="Radiochemistry">radiochemistry</a> and discovered <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fission" title="Nuclear fission">nuclear fission</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Cohn" title="Ferdinand Cohn">Ferdinand Cohn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Koch" title="Robert Koch">Robert Koch</a> were founders of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microbiology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microbiology (page does not exist)">microbiology</a>. Numerous <a href="/wiki/Mathematician" title="Mathematician">mathematicians</a> were born in Germany, including <a href="/wiki/Carl_Friedrich_Gauss" title="Carl Friedrich Gauss">Carl Friedrich Gauss</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Hilbert" title="David Hilbert">David Hilbert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bernhard_Riemann" title="Bernhard Riemann">Bernhard Riemann</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottfried_Leibniz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottfried Leibniz (page does not exist)">Gottfried Leibniz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karl_Weierstrass" title="Karl Weierstrass">Karl Weierstrass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Weyl" title="Hermann Weyl">Hermann Weyl</a> and <a href="/wiki/Felix_Klein" title="Felix Klein">Felix Klein</a>. Research institutions in Germany include the <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck_Society" title="Max Planck Society">Max Planck Society</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Helmholtz_Association_of_German_Research_Centres" title="Helmholtz Association of German Research Centres">Helmholtz Association</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Fraunhofer_Society" title="Fraunhofer Society">Fraunhofer Society</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz_Prize&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize (page does not exist)">Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Prize</a> is granted to ten scientists and academics every year. With a maximum of €2.5&#160;million  per award it is one of highest endowed research prizes in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germany has been the home of many famous inventors and <a href="/wiki/Engineer" title="Engineer">engineers</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Gutenberg" title="Johannes Gutenberg">Johannes Gutenberg</a>, credited with the invention of <a href="/wiki/Movable_type" title="Movable type">movable type</a> printing in Europe; <a href="/wiki/Hans_Geiger" title="Hans Geiger">Hans Geiger</a>, the creator of the <a href="/wiki/Geiger_counter" title="Geiger counter">Geiger counter</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Konrad_Zuse" title="Konrad Zuse">Konrad Zuse</a>, who built the first fully automatic digital computer.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> German inventors, engineers and industrialists such as Count <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_von_Zeppelin" title="Ferdinand von Zeppelin">Ferdinand von Zeppelin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otto_Lilienthal" title="Otto Lilienthal">Otto Lilienthal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gottlieb_Daimler" title="Gottlieb Daimler">Gottlieb Daimler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Diesel" title="Rudolf Diesel">Rudolf Diesel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Junkers" title="Hugo Junkers">Hugo Junkers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karl_Benz" title="Karl Benz">Karl Benz</a> helped shape modern automotive and air transportation technology.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aerospace_engineering&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aerospace engineering (page does not exist)">Aerospace engineer</a> <a href="/wiki/Wernher_von_Braun" title="Wernher von Braun">Wernher von Braun</a> developed the <a href="/wiki/V-2_rocket" title="V-2 rocket">first space rocket</a> and later on was a prominent member of <a href="/w/index.php?title=NASA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NASA (page does not exist)">NASA</a> and developed the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saturn_V&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saturn V (page does not exist)">Saturn V</a> Moon rocket, which paved the way for the success of the US <a href="/w/index.php?title=Apollo_programme&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Apollo programme (page does not exist)">Apollo programme</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Heinrich_Rudolf_Hertz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Heinrich Rudolf Hertz (page does not exist)">Heinrich Rudolf Hertz</a>'s work in the domain of <a href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation" title="Electromagnetic radiation">electromagnetic radiation</a> was pivotal to the development of modern telecommunication.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germany is one of the leading countries in developing and using green technologies. Companies specialising in <a href="/wiki/Green_technology" title="Green technology" class="mw-redirect">green technology</a> have an estimated turnover of €200 billion. Key sectors of Germany's green technology industry are power generation, sustainable mobility, material efficiency, energy efficiency, waste management and <a href="/wiki/Recycling" title="Recycling">recycling</a>, and sustainable <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_management&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water management (page does not exist)">water management</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>With a population of 80.2&#160;million according to the May 2011 census,<sup id="cite_ref-File_2013_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-File_2013-6">[6]</a></sup> Germany is the most populous country in the European Union, the second most populous country in Europe after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, and ranks as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">16th most populous country</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">population density</a> stands at 225 inhabitants per square kilometre. The overall <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by life expectancy (page does not exist)">life expectancy in Germany</a> at birth is 80.19 years (77.93 years for males and 82.58 years for females).<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">fertility rate</a> of 1.41 children born per woman (2011 estimates), or 8.33 births per 1000 inhabitants, is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_fertility_rate" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate">lowest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup> Since the 1970s, Germany's <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" title="Death rate" class="mw-redirect">death rate</a> has continuously exceeded its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Federal_Statistical_Office_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Federal Statistical Office of Germany (page does not exist)">Federal Statistical Office of Germany</a> has forecast that the population could shrink to between 65 and 70 million by 2060 (depending on the level of net migration).<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>
However, such forecasts have often been proven wrong in the past, and Germany is currently witnessing increased birth rates<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> and migration rates since the beginning of the 2010s. It is notably experiencing a strong increase in the number of well-educated migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> In 2012, 300,000 more immigrants than emigrants were reported in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_of_German_territories_1800_-_2000.JPG" title="File:Population of German territories 1800 - 2000.JPG">File:Population of German territories 1800 - 2000.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Development of German population since 1800</div></div></div>
<p>Germans by nationality make up 92.3% of the population of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-File_2013_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-File_2013-6">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a> and about six million foreign citizens (7.7% of the population) were registered in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-File_2013_6-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-File_2013-6">[6]</a></sup> Regarding ethnic background, 20%<sup id="cite_ref-pop_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pop-143">[143]</a></sup> of the country's residents, or more than 16 million people, were of foreign or partially foreign descent (including persons descending or partially descending from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethnic_German&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethnic German (page does not exist)">ethnic German</a> repatriates), 96% of whom lived in the former West Germany or Berlin.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> In 2010, 2.3 million families with children under 18 years were living in Germany, in which at least one parent had foreign roots. They represented 29% of the total of 8.1 million families with minor children. Compared with 2005 – the year when the microcensus started to collect detailed information on the population with a migrant background – the proportion of migrant families has risen by 2 percentage points.<sup id="cite_ref-destatis.de_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-destatis.de-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the families with a migrant background live in the western part of Germany. In 2010, the proportion of migrant families in all families was 32% in the pre-unification territory of the Federal Republic. This figure was more than double that in the new Länder (including Berlin) where it stood at 15%.<sup id="cite_ref-destatis.de_145-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-destatis.de-145">[145]</a></sup> Families with a migrant background more often have three or more minor children in the household than families without a migrant background. In 2010, about 15% of the families with a migrant background contained three or more minor children, as compared with just 9% of the families without a migrant background.<sup id="cite_ref-destatis.de_145-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-destatis.de-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Population_Fund" title="United Nations Population Fund">United Nations Population Fund</a> lists Germany as host to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_immigrant_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by immigrant population (page does not exist)">third-highest number of international migrants worldwide</a>, about 5% or 10&#160;million of all 191&#160;million migrants.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> As a consequence of <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Germany" title="Immigration to Germany">restrictions</a> to Germany's formerly rather unrestricted laws on <a href="/wiki/Right_of_asylum" title="Right of asylum">asylum</a> and immigration, the number of immigrants seeking asylum or claiming German ethnicity (mostly from the former Soviet Union) has been declining steadily since 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> In 2009, 20% of the population had immigrant roots, the highest since 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the largest national group was from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a> (2.5&#160;million), followed by <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> (776,000) and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (687,000).<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> About 3&#160;million "Aussiedler"—ethnic Germans, mainly from the former eastern bloc—have <a href="/wiki/Right_of_return#Germany" title="Right of return">resettled</a> in Germany since 1987.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Large numbers of people with full or significant German ancestry are found in the United States,<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Brazil,<sup id="cite_ref-The_German_Times_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_German_Times-152">[152]</a></sup> Argentina<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> and Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
Most ethnic minorities (especially those of non-European origin) reside in large urban areas like <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frankfurt_Rhine-Main&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frankfurt Rhine-Main (page does not exist)">Frankfurt Rhine-Main</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhine-Ruhr" title="Rhine-Ruhr">Rhine-Ruhr</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rhine-Neckar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rhine-Neckar (page does not exist)">Rhine-Neckar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Munich" title="Munich">Munich</a>. The percentage of non-Germans and immigrants is rather low in rural areas and small towns, especially in the East German states of the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Democratic_Republic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Democratic Republic (page does not exist)">GDR territory</a>.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pie_chart&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pie chart (page does not exist)">Template:Pie chart</a>
</p><p>Germany is home to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_immigrant_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by immigrant population (page does not exist)">third-highest number of international migrants worldwide</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
Ethnic composition in 2010:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr>

</th>
<th> population <sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</th></tr>

</td>
<td>  3,208,788
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td>

</td></tr>
<tr>
