</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> Total population
</td>
<td> <b>100</b>
</td>
<td> 80,219,695
</td></tr></table>
<p>Germany has a number of large <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities in Germany (page does not exist)">cities</a>. There are 11 officially recognised <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metropolitan_regions_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metropolitan regions in Germany (page does not exist)">metropolitan regions</a> in Germany – and since 2006, 34 potential cities were identified which can be called a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regiopolis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regiopolis (page does not exist)">Regiopolis</a>.
The largest <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">conurbation</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Rhine-Ruhr" title="Rhine-Ruhr">Rhine-Ruhr</a> region (11.7&#160;million <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>), including <a href="/wiki/D%C3%BCsseldorf" title="Düsseldorf">Düsseldorf</a> (the capital of <a href="/wiki/North_Rhine-Westphalia" title="North Rhine-Westphalia">North Rhine-Westphalia</a>), <a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bonn" title="Bonn">Bonn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dortmund" title="Dortmund">Dortmund</a>, <a href="/wiki/Essen" title="Essen">Essen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duisburg" title="Duisburg">Duisburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bochum" title="Bochum">Bochum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><br style="clear:both;" />
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest cities of Germany (page does not exist)">Template:Largest cities of Germany</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> is the largest religion in Germany, with around 51.5&#160;million adherents (62.8%) in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-ekd_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ekd-161">[161]</a></sup> Relative to the whole population, 30.0% of Germans are <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a>, 29.9% are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protestantism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protestantism (page does not exist)">Protestants</a> belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Church_in_Germany" title="Evangelical Church in Germany">Evangelical Church in Germany</a> (EKD), and the remaining Christians belong to smaller denominations each with less than 0.5% of the German population.<sup id="cite_ref-fowid_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fowid-162">[162]</a></sup> Protestantism is concentrated in the north and east and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in Germany (page does not exist)">Roman
Catholicism</a> is concentrated in the south and west;<sup id="cite_ref-georgetown1_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-163">[163]</a></sup> 1.6% of the country's overall population declare themselves <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Christians" title="Orthodox Christians" class="mw-redirect">Orthodox Christians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ekd_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ekd-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>The second largest religion is <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Germany" title="Islam in Germany">Islam</a> with an estimated 3.8 to 4.3&#160;million adherents (4.6% to 5.2%),<sup id="cite_ref-MLD_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MLD-164">[164]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> with 250,000 and <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> with around 200,000 adherents (0.3%); <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> has some 90,000 adherents (0.1%). All other religious communities in Germany have fewer than 50,000 adherents.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Of the roughly 4&#160;million Muslims, most are <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunnis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alevites" title="Alevites" class="mw-redirect">Alevites</a> from Turkey, but there are a small number of <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">Shi'ites</a> and other denominations.<sup id="cite_ref-MLD_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MLD-164">[164]</a></sup> German Muslims, a large portion of whom are of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkish</a> origin, lack full official state recognition of their religious community.<sup id="cite_ref-georgetown1_163-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-163">[163]</a></sup> Germany has Europe's third largest <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Germany" title="History of the Jews in Germany">Jewish population</a> (after France and the United Kingdom).<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> Approximately 50% of the Buddhists in Germany are Asian immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germans with no stated religious adherence make up 34.1% of the population and are concentrated in the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Democratic_Republic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Democratic Republic (page does not exist)">East Germany</a> and major metropolitan areas.<sup id="cite_ref-fowid_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fowid-162">[162]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/German_reunification" title="German reunification">German reunification</a> in 1990 greatly increased the country's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-religious&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-religious (page does not exist)">non-religious</a> population, a legacy of the <a href="/wiki/State_atheism" title="State atheism">state atheism</a> of the previously <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a>-controlled East. Christian church membership has decreased in recent decades, particularly among Protestants.<sup id="cite_ref-georgetown1_163-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown1-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Knowledge_German_EU_map.png" title="File:Knowledge German EU map.png">File:Knowledge German EU map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German language</a> is the most widely spoken first language in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, with around 100 million native speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-Marten_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marten-168">[168]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>German is the official and predominant spoken language in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_Languages_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_Languages-169">[169]</a></sup> It is one of 23 official languages in the European Union, and one of the three <a href="/w/index.php?title=Working_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Working language (page does not exist)">working languages</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a>.
</p><p>Recognised native minority languages in Germany are <a href="/wiki/Danish_language" title="Danish language">Danish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sorbian_languages" title="Sorbian languages">Sorbian</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Romany_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Romany language (page does not exist)">Romany</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Frisian_languages" title="Frisian languages">Frisian</a>; they are officially protected by the <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>. The most used immigrant languages are <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kurdish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kurdish language (page does not exist)">Kurdish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balkan_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balkan languages (page does not exist)">Balkan languages</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>. 67% of German citizens claim to be able to communicate in at least one foreign language and 27% in at least two languages other than their own.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_Languages_169-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_Languages-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Standard German is a <a href="/wiki/West_Germanic_languages" title="West Germanic languages">West Germanic language</a> and is closely related to and classified alongside English, <a href="/wiki/Low_German" title="Low German">Low German</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dutch_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dutch language (page does not exist)">Dutch</a>, and the Frisian languages. To a lesser extent, it is also related to the <a href="/wiki/East_Germanic_languages" title="East Germanic languages">East</a> (extinct) and <a href="/wiki/North_Germanic_languages" title="North Germanic languages">North Germanic languages</a>. Most German vocabulary is derived from the Germanic branch of the Indo-European language family.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> Significant minorities of words are derived from Latin and Greek, with a smaller amount from French and most recently English (known as <a href="/wiki/Denglisch" title="Denglisch">Denglisch</a>). German is written using the Latin alphabet. German <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">dialects</a>, traditional local varieties traced back to the Germanic tribes, are distinguished from <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">varieties</a> of <a href="/wiki/Standard_German" title="Standard German">standard German</a> by their <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">lexicon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">phonology</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Syntax" title="Syntax">syntax</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Heidelberg_Universit%C3%A4tsbibliothek_2003.jpg" title="File:Heidelberg Universitätsbibliothek 2003.jpg">File:Heidelberg Universitätsbibliothek 2003.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Heidelberg_University" title="Heidelberg University">Heidelberg University</a> is the oldest <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Germany" title="List of universities in Germany">university of Germany</a> and among its best ranked.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> It was established in 1386.</div></div></div>
<p>Over 99% of Germans age 15 and above are estimated to be able to read and write.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_57-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-57">[57]</a></sup> Responsibility for educational supervision in Germany is primarily organised within the individual <a href="/wiki/States_of_Germany" title="States of Germany">federal states</a>. Since the 1960s, a reform movement attempted to unify secondary education in a <i>Gesamtschule</i> (<a href="/wiki/Comprehensive_school" title="Comprehensive school">comprehensive school</a>); several West German states later simplified their school system to two or three tiers. A system of apprenticeship called <i>Duale Ausbildung</i> ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=Dual_education_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dual education system (page does not exist)">dual education</a>") allows pupils in <a href="/wiki/Vocational_training" title="Vocational training" class="mw-redirect">vocational training</a> to learn in a company as well as in a state-run vocational school.<sup id="cite_ref-ED_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ED-173">[173]</a></sup> This successful model is highly regarded and reproduced all around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>Optional <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">kindergarten</a> education is provided for all children between three and six years old, after which school attendance is <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_education" title="Compulsory education">compulsory</a> for at least nine years. Primary education usually lasts for four to six years and public schools are not stratified at this stage.<sup id="cite_ref-ED_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ED-173">[173]</a></sup> In contrast, secondary education includes three traditional types of schools focused on different levels of academic ability: the <i><a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">Gymnasium</a></i> enrols the most gifted children and prepares students for university studies; the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Realschule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Realschule (page does not exist)">Realschule</a></i> for intermediate students lasts six years; the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hauptschule&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hauptschule (page does not exist)">Hauptschule</a></i> prepares pupils for vocational education.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stellarator_Wendelstein_7-X_Reaktorgestell.jpg" title="File:Stellarator Wendelstein 7-X Reaktorgestell.jpg">File:Stellarator Wendelstein 7-X Reaktorgestell.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wendelstein_7-X&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wendelstein 7-X (page does not exist)">Wendelstein 7-X</a>, a research facility at <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck_Institute_of_Plasma_Physics" title="Max Planck Institute of Plasma Physics">Max Planck Institute of Plasma Physics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greifswald" title="Greifswald">Greifswald</a>. Much of the research in Germany is done in independent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Category:Research_institutes_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category:Research institutes in Germany (page does not exist)">institutes</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The general entrance requirement for university is <a href="/wiki/Abitur" title="Abitur">Abitur</a>, a qualification normally based on continuous assessment during the last few years at school and final examinations; however there are a number of exceptions, and precise requirements vary, depending on the state, the university and the subject. Germany's universities are recognised internationally; in the <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">Academic Ranking of World Universities</a> (ARWU) for 2008, six of the top 100 universities in the world are in Germany, and 18 of the top 200.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Most of the German universities are public institutions, charging tuition fees of only around €60 per semester (and up to €500 in the state of <a href="/wiki/Niedersachsen" title="Niedersachsen" class="mw-redirect">Niedersachsen</a>) for each student.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> Thus, academic education is open to most citizens and studying is increasingly common in Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Although the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dual_education_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dual education system (page does not exist)">dual education system</a>, that combines practical and theoretical educations and does not lead to academic degrees, is typical for Germany and recognised as a role model for other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Germany" title="List of universities in Germany">universities of Germany</a> are also among the oldest and best regarded in the world, with <a href="/wiki/Heidelberg_University" title="Heidelberg University">Heidelberg University</a> being the oldest (established in 1386 and in continuous operation since then). It is followed by <a href="/wiki/Leipzig_University" title="Leipzig University">Leipzig University</a> (1409), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Rostock" title="University of Rostock">Rostock University</a> (1419), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Greifswald" title="University of Greifswald">Greifswald University</a> (1456), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Freiburg" title="University of Freiburg">Freiburg University</a> (1457), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Munich" title="University of Munich" class="mw-redirect">LMU Munich</a> (1472) and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_T%C3%BCbingen" title="University of Tübingen">University of Tübingen</a> (1477).
</p><p>German universities traditionally emphasize the combination of teaching and research. In addition, research is performed at independent non-university research institutions, such as within <a href="/wiki/Max_Planck_Society" title="Max Planck Society">Max Planck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fraunhofer_Society" title="Fraunhofer Society">Fraunhofer</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottfried_Wilhelm_Leibniz_Scientific_Community&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz Scientific Community (page does not exist)">Leibniz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Helmholtz_Association_of_German_Research_Centres" title="Helmholtz Association of German Research Centres">Helmholtz</a> institutes. Many of these institutions have also established close connections with nearby universities.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Luebeck-Heiligen-Geist-Hospital_von_Westen_gesehen-20100905.jpg" title="File:Luebeck-Heiligen-Geist-Hospital von Westen gesehen-20100905.jpg">File:Luebeck-Heiligen-Geist-Hospital von Westen gesehen-20100905.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Hospice of the Holy Spirit</i> in <a href="/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck" title="Lübeck">Lübeck</a> - one of the world's oldest social institutions and a precursor to modern hospitals</div></div></div>
<p>Germany has the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system, dating back to <a href="/wiki/Otto_von_Bismarck#Bismarck.27s_social_legislation" title="Otto von Bismarck">Bismarck's social legislation</a> in 1883.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Currently the population is covered by a fairly comprehensive health insurance plan provided by statute. Certain groups of people (lifetime officials, self-employed persons, employees with high income) can opt out of the plan and switch to a private insurance contract. Previously, these groups could also choose to do without insurance, but this option was dropped in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, Germany's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Health_care_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Health care system (page does not exist)">health care system</a> was 77% government-funded and 23% privately funded <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-health_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health-183">[183]</a></sup> In 2005, Germany spent 11% of its GDP on health care. Germany ranked 20th in the world in life expectancy with <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by life expectancy (page does not exist)">77 years for men and 82 years for women</a>, and it had a very low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" title="Infant mortality rate" class="mw-redirect">infant mortality rate</a> (4 per 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">live births</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-health_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health-183">[183]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, the principal cause of death was cardiovascular disease, at 41%, followed by malignant tumours, at 26%.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, about 82,000 Germans had been infected with HIV/AIDS and 26,000 had died from the disease (cumulatively, since 1982).<sup id="cite_ref-cp_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cp-185">[185]</a></sup>
According to a 2005 survey, 27% of German adults are smokers.<sup id="cite_ref-cp_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cp-185">[185]</a></sup>
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beethoven.jpg" title="File:Beethoven.jpg">File:Beethoven.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a> (1770–1827), composer</div></div></div>
<p>From its roots, culture in German states has been shaped by major intellectual and popular currents in Europe, both religious and <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secular</a>. Historically Germany has been called <i>Das Land der Dichter und Denker</i> ("the land of poets and thinkers"),<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup> because of the major role its famous <a href="/wiki/German_literature" title="German literature">writers</a> and <a href="/wiki/German_philosophy" title="German philosophy">philosophers</a> have played in the development of Western thought and culture.
</p><p>The federated states are in charge of the cultural institutions. There are 240 subsidised theatres, hundreds of symphonic orchestras, thousands of museums and over 25,000 libraries spread in Germany. These cultural opportunities are enjoyed by many: there are over 91&#160;million German museum visits every year; annually, 20&#160;million go to theatres and operas; 3.6&#160;million per year listen to the symphonic orchestras.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> As of 2012 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> inscribed 37 properties in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Table_of_World_Heritage_Sites_by_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Table of World Heritage Sites by country (page does not exist)">Germany on the World Heritage List</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germany has established a high level of <a href="/wiki/Gender_equality" title="Gender equality">gender equality</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> promotes <a href="/wiki/Disability_rights_movement" title="Disability rights movement">disability rights</a>, and is legally and socially tolerant towards homosexuals. Gays and lesbians can legally adopt their partner's biological children, and <a href="/wiki/Civil_union" title="Civil union">civil unions</a> have been permitted since 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> Germany has also changed its attitude towards immigrants; since the mid-1990s, the government and the majority of Germans have begun to acknowledge that controlled immigration should be allowed based on qualification standards.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> Germany has been named the world's second most valued nation among 50 countries in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> A global opinion poll for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a> revealed that Germany is recognised for having the most positive influence in the world in 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> and for being the most positively viewed nation in the world, in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Caspar_David_Friedrich_023.jpg" title="File:Caspar David Friedrich 023.jpg">File:Caspar David Friedrich 023.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chalk_Cliffs_on_R%C3%BCgen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chalk Cliffs on Rügen (page does not exist)">Chalk Cliffs on Rügen</a></i> (1818) by <a href="/wiki/Caspar_David_Friedrich" title="Caspar David Friedrich">Caspar David Friedrich</a>, the most prominent artist of <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a></div></div></div>
<p>Numerous German painters have enjoyed international prestige through their work in diverse artistic styles. <a href="/wiki/Albrecht_D%C3%BCrer" title="Albrecht Dürer">Albrecht Dürer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hans_Holbein_the_Younger" title="Hans Holbein the Younger">Hans Holbein the Younger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Matthias_Gr%C3%BCnewald" title="Matthias Grünewald">Matthias Grünewald</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lucas_Cranach_the_Elder" title="Lucas Cranach the Elder">Lucas Cranach the Elder</a> were important artists of the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Paul_Rubens&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Paul Rubens (page does not exist)">Peter Paul Rubens</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Baptist_Zimmermann&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Baptist Zimmermann (page does not exist)">Johann Baptist Zimmermann</a> of <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caspar_David_Friedrich" title="Caspar David Friedrich">Caspar David Friedrich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carl_Spitzweg" title="Carl Spitzweg">Carl Spitzweg</a> of <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Max_Liebermann" title="Max Liebermann">Max Liebermann</a> of <a href="/wiki/Impressionism" title="Impressionism">Impressionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Max_Ernst" title="Max Ernst">Max Ernst</a> of <a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">Surrealism</a>.
</p><p>Several German artist groups formed in the 20th century, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=November_Group_(German)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="November Group (German) (page does not exist)">November Group</a> or <a href="/wiki/Die_Br%C3%BCcke" title="Die Brücke">Die Brücke</a> (The Bridge) and <a href="/wiki/Der_Blaue_Reiter" title="Der Blaue Reiter">Der Blaue Reiter</a> (The Blue Rider) in <a href="/wiki/Expressionism" title="Expressionism">Expressionism</a>. The <a href="/wiki/New_Objectivity" title="New Objectivity">New Objectivity</a> arose as a counter-style to it during the <a href="/wiki/Weimar_Republic" title="Weimar Republic">Weimar Republic</a>. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_2" title="World War 2" class="mw-redirect">WWII</a>, main movements of <a href="/wiki/Neo-expressionism" title="Neo-expressionism">Neo-expressionism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Performance_art" title="Performance art">performance art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Conceptual_art" title="Conceptual art">Conceptual art</a> evolved, with notable artists such as <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Beuys" title="Joseph Beuys">Joseph Beuys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gerhard_Richter" title="Gerhard Richter">Gerhard Richter</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%B6rg_Immendorff" title="Jörg Immendorff">Jörg Immendorff</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=HA_Schult&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="HA Schult (page does not exist)">HA Schult</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aris_Kalaizis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aris Kalaizis (page does not exist)">Aris Kalaizis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neo_Rauch" title="Neo Rauch">Neo Rauch</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Leipzig_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Leipzig School (page does not exist)">New Leipzig School</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Andreas_Gursky" title="Andreas Gursky">Andreas Gursky</a> (photography). Major art exhibitions and festivals in Germany are the <a href="/wiki/Documenta" title="Documenta">documenta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Transmediale" title="Transmediale">transmediale</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Art_Cologne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Art Cologne (page does not exist)">Art Cologne</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; float:left; margin-left:1em">

<tr>
<th align="right"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Sebastian_Bach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Sebastian Bach (page does not exist)">J.S. Bach</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Toccata_and_Fugue_in_D_minor,_BWV_565" title="Toccata and Fugue in D minor, BWV 565">Toccata und Fuge</a></small>
</th>
<th align="right"><a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">L.v. Beethoven</a><br /><small><a href="/w/index.php?title=Symphony_No._5_(Beethoven)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Symphony No. 5 (Beethoven) (page does not exist)">Symphonie 5 c-moll</a></small>
</th>
<th align="right"><a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner" title="Richard Wagner">R. Wagner</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Die_Walk%C3%BCre" title="Die Walküre">Die Walküre</a></small>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:left; background:#dcdcdc;"> <a href="/wiki/File:Toccata_et_Fugue_BWV565.ogg" title="File:Toccata et Fugue BWV565.ogg">100px</a> </td>
<td style="text-align:left; background:#d3d3d3;"> <a href="/wiki/File:Ludwig_van_Beethoven_-_Symphonie_5_c-moll_-_1._Allegro_con_brio.ogg" title="File:Ludwig van Beethoven - Symphonie 5 c-moll - 1. Allegro con brio.ogg">100px</a></td>
<td style="text-align:left; background:silver;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wagner_-_die_walkure_fantasie.ogg" title="File:Wagner - die walkure fantasie.ogg">100px</a>
</td></tr></table>
<p>German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Classical_music_era&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Classical music era (page does not exist)">classical music</a> comprises works by some of the world's most well-known composers, including <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_van_Beethoven" title="Ludwig van Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Sebastian_Bach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Sebastian Bach (page does not exist)">Johann Sebastian Bach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wolfgang_Amadeus_Mozart" title="Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart">Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Johannes_Brahms" title="Johannes Brahms">Johannes Brahms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner" title="Richard Wagner">Richard Wagner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Strauss" title="Richard Strauss">Richard Strauss</a>.
</p><p>Germany is the largest music market in Europe, and third largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> German popular music of the 20th and 21st century includes the movements of <a href="/wiki/Neue_Deutsche_Welle" title="Neue Deutsche Welle">Neue Deutsche Welle</a> (<a href="/wiki/Nena" title="Nena">Nena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alphaville_(band)" title="Alphaville (band)">Alphaville</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ostrock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ostrock (page does not exist)">Ostrock</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=City_(band)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City (band) (page does not exist)">City</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Keimzeit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Keimzeit (page does not exist)">Keimzeit</a>), <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">Metal</a>/<a href="/wiki/German_rock" title="German rock">Rock</a> (<a href="/wiki/Rammstein" title="Rammstein">Rammstein</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scorpions_(band)" title="Scorpions (band)">Scorpions</a>), <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_punk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German punk (page does not exist)">Punk</a> (<a href="/wiki/Die_%C3%84rzte" title="Die Ärzte">Die Ärzte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Die_Toten_Hosen" title="Die Toten Hosen">Die Toten Hosen</a>), <a href="/wiki/Pop_rock" title="Pop rock">Pop rock</a> (<a href="/wiki/Beatsteaks" title="Beatsteaks">Beatsteaks</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tokio_Hotel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tokio Hotel (page does not exist)">Tokio Hotel</a>), <a href="/wiki/Indie_rock" title="Indie rock">Indie</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tocotronic" title="Tocotronic">Tocotronic</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Blumfeld&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blumfeld (page does not exist)">Blumfeld</a>) and <a href="/wiki/German_hip_hop" title="German hip hop">Hip Hop</a> (<a href="/wiki/Die_Fantastischen_Vier" title="Die Fantastischen Vier">Die Fantastischen Vier</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deichkind&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deichkind (page does not exist)">Deichkind</a>). Especially the German <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">Electronic music</a> gained global influence, with <a href="/wiki/Kraftwerk" title="Kraftwerk">Kraftwerk</a> being a pioneer group in this genre,<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Minimal_music" title="Minimal music">Minimal</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Techno&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Techno (page does not exist)">Techno</a> scenes in Germany being very popular (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Paul_van_Dyk" title="Paul van Dyk">Paul van Dyk</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tomcraft&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tomcraft (page does not exist)">Tomcraft</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_Kalkbrenner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul Kalkbrenner (page does not exist)">Paul Kalkbrenner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(band)" title="Scooter (band)">Scooter</a>).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Heringsdorf_Seeschloss.JPG" title="File:Heringsdorf Seeschloss.JPG">File:Heringsdorf Seeschloss.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The "Sea Castle" on <a href="/wiki/Usedom" title="Usedom">Usedom Island</a>,  a typical example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Resort_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Resort architecture (page does not exist)">Resort architecture</a>. This style is common at the German <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> coast.</div></div></div>
<p>Architectural contributions from Germany include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carolingian_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carolingian architecture (page does not exist)">Carolingian</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ottonian_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ottonian architecture (page does not exist)">Ottonian styles</a>, which were precursors of <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_architecture" title="Romanesque architecture">Romanesque</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brick_Gothic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brick Gothic (page does not exist)">Brick Gothic</a> in medieval times and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brick_Expressionism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brick Expressionism (page does not exist)">Brick Expressionism</a> in modern times are two distinctive styles that developed in Germany. Also in <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_architecture" title="Renaissance architecture">Renaissance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">Baroque</a> art, regional and typically German elements evolved (e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Weser_Renaissance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Weser Renaissance (page does not exist)">Weser Renaissance</a> and <i><a href="/wiki/Dresden" title="Dresden">Dresden</a> Baroque</i>). Among many renowned Baroque masters were <a href="/wiki/Matth%C3%A4us_Daniel_P%C3%B6ppelmann" title="Matthäus Daniel Pöppelmann">Pöppelmann</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Balthasar_Neumann&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Balthasar Neumann (page does not exist)">Balthasar Neumann</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georg_Wenzeslaus_von_Knobelsdorff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georg Wenzeslaus von Knobelsdorff (page does not exist)">Knobelsdorff</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asam_brothers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asam brothers (page does not exist)">Asam brothers</a>.
</p><p>Germany is especially renowned for its <a href="/wiki/Timber_framing" title="Timber framing">timber frame</a> old towns, with many well-kept examples to be found along the <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_Timber-Frame_Road&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German Timber-Frame Road (page does not exist)">German Timber-Frame Road</a>, leading from the very <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southern_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southern Germany (page does not exist)">south of Germany</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Germany (page does not exist)">Northern Germany</a> and its coasts.
</p><p>When industrialisation spread across Europe, <a href="/wiki/Classicism" title="Classicism">Classicism</a> and a distinctive style of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Historicism_(art)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Historicism (art) (page does not exist)">historism</a> developed in Germany, sometimes referred to as <i><a href="/wiki/Gr%C3%BCnderzeit" title="Gründerzeit">Gründerzeit</a> style</i>, due to the economical boom years at the end of the 19th century. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Resort_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Resort architecture (page does not exist)">Resort architecture</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spa_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spa architecture (page does not exist)">Spa architecture</a> are sub-styles, that evolved since the 18th century in Germany, with the first modern <a href="/wiki/Spa" title="Spa">spas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seaside_resort" title="Seaside resort">Seaside resorts</a> of Europe. Many architects formed this era, with <a href="/wiki/Karl_Friedrich_Schinkel" title="Karl Friedrich Schinkel">Schinkel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gottfried_Semper" title="Gottfried Semper">Semper</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Friedrich_August_St%C3%BCler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Friedrich August Stüler (page does not exist)">Stüler</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Friedrich_von_G%C3%A4rtner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Friedrich von Gärtner (page does not exist)">von Gärtner</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Franz_Heinrich_Schwechten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Franz Heinrich Schwechten (page does not exist)">Schwechten</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constantin_Lipsius&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constantin Lipsius (page does not exist)">Lipsius</a> among them.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Jugendstil</a> became a dominant architectural style at the turn of the 19th to the 20th century, with a strong influence of the Art Nouveau movement.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-197">[197]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> movement did not gain much influence in Germany, instead the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Expressionist_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Expressionist architecture (page does not exist)">Expressionist architecture</a> spread across the country, with e.g. <a href="/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_H%C3%B6ger" title="Johann Friedrich Höger">Höger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erich_Mendelsohn" title="Erich Mendelsohn">Mendelsohn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominikus_B%C3%B6hm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominikus Böhm (page does not exist)">Böhm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fritz_Schumacher_(architect)" title="Fritz Schumacher (architect)">Schumacher</a> being influential architects.
</p><p>Germany was particularly important in the early <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">modern movement</a> - it is the home of the <a href="/wiki/Bauhaus" title="Bauhaus">Bauhaus</a> movement founded by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Gropius" title="Walter Gropius">Walter Gropius</a>. And thus Germany is a cradle of <a href="/wiki/Modern_architecture" title="Modern architecture">modern architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Ludwig_Mies_van_der_Rohe" title="Ludwig Mies van der Rohe">Ludwig Mies van der Rohe</a> became one of the world's most renowned architects in the second half of the 20th century. He conceived of the glass façade skyscraper.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup>
</p><p>Renowned contemporary architects include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hans_Kollhoff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hans Kollhoff (page does not exist)">Hans Kollhoff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Helmut_Jahn" title="Helmut Jahn">Helmut Jahn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Behnisch_Architekten&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Behnisch Architekten (page does not exist)">Behnisch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Speer,_Jr." title="Albert Speer, Jr.">Albert Speer Junior</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frei_Otto" title="Frei Otto">Frei Otto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oswald_Mathias_Ungers" title="Oswald Mathias Ungers">Oswald Mathias Ungers</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottfried_B%C3%B6hm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottfried Böhm (page does not exist)">Gottfried Böhm</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephan_Braunfels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephan Braunfels (page does not exist)">Stephan Braunfels</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anna_Heringer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anna Heringer (page does not exist)">Anna Heringer</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Grimm.jpg" title="File:Grimm.jpg">File:Grimm.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Brothers_Grimm" title="Brothers Grimm">Brothers Grimm</a></div></div></div>
<p>German literature can be traced back to the Middle Ages and the works of writers such as <a href="/wiki/Walther_von_der_Vogelweide" title="Walther von der Vogelweide">Walther von der Vogelweide</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wolfram_von_Eschenbach" title="Wolfram von Eschenbach">Wolfram von Eschenbach</a>. Well-known German authors include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johann_Wolfgang_von_Goethe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (page does not exist)">Johann Wolfgang von Goethe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Schiller" title="Friedrich Schiller">Friedrich Schiller</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gotthold_Ephraim_Lessing" title="Gotthold Ephraim Lessing">Gotthold Ephraim Lessing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Theodor_Fontane" title="Theodor Fontane">Theodor Fontane</a>. The collections of folk tales published by the <a href="/wiki/Brothers_Grimm" title="Brothers Grimm">Brothers Grimm</a> popularised <a href="/wiki/German_folklore" title="German folklore">German folklore</a> on an international level. Influential authors of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Gerhart_Hauptmann" title="Gerhart Hauptmann">Gerhart Hauptmann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Mann" title="Thomas Mann">Thomas Mann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Hesse" title="Hermann Hesse">Hermann Hesse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heinrich_B%C3%B6ll" title="Heinrich Böll">Heinrich Böll</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=G%C3%BCnter_Grass&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Günter Grass (page does not exist)">Günter Grass</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> German-speaking book publishers produce some 700&#160;million books every year, with about 80,000 titles, nearly 60,000 of them new. Germany comes third in quantity of books published, after the English-speaking book market and the People's Republic of China.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Book_Fair" title="Frankfurt Book Fair">Frankfurt Book Fair</a> is the most important in the world for international deals and trading, with a tradition spanning over 500 years.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>German philosophy is historically significant. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gottfried_Leibniz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gottfried Leibniz (page does not exist)">Gottfried Leibniz</a>'s contributions to <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">rationalism</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">enlightenment</a> philosophy by <a href="/wiki/Immanuel_Kant" title="Immanuel Kant">Immanuel Kant</a>; the establishment of classical <a href="/wiki/German_idealism" title="German idealism">German idealism</a> by <a href="/wiki/Johann_Gottlieb_Fichte" title="Johann Gottlieb Fichte">Johann Gottlieb Fichte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georg_Wilhelm_Friedrich_Hegel" title="Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel">Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Wilhelm_Joseph_Schelling" title="Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling">Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling</a>; <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Schopenhauer" title="Arthur Schopenhauer">Arthur Schopenhauer</a>'s composition of metaphysical pessimism; the formulation of <a href="/wiki/Communist_theory" title="Communist theory" class="mw-redirect">communist theory</a> by <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a> and <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Engels" title="Friedrich Engels">Friedrich Engels</a>; <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Nietzsche" title="Friedrich Nietzsche">Friedrich Nietzsche</a>'s development of <a href="/wiki/Perspectivism" title="Perspectivism">perspectivism</a>; <a href="/wiki/Gottlob_Frege" title="Gottlob Frege">Gottlob Frege</a>'s contributions to the dawn of <a href="/wiki/Analytic_philosophy" title="Analytic philosophy">analytic philosophy</a>; <a href="/wiki/Martin_Heidegger" title="Martin Heidegger">Martin Heidegger</a>'s works on Being; and the development of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frankfurt_school&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frankfurt school (page does not exist)">Frankfurt school</a> by <a href="/wiki/Max_Horkheimer" title="Max Horkheimer">Max Horkheimer</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Theodor_Adorno&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Theodor Adorno (page does not exist)">Theodor Adorno</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Herbert_Marcuse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Herbert Marcuse (page does not exist)">Herbert Marcuse</a> and <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Habermas" title="Jürgen Habermas">Jürgen Habermas</a> have been particularly influential. In the 21st century, Germany has contributed to the development of contemporary analytic philosophy in continental Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fritz_Lang_-_Boulevard_der_Stars.jpg" title="File:Fritz Lang - Boulevard der Stars.jpg">File:Fritz Lang - Boulevard der Stars.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Star of <a href="/wiki/Fritz_Lang" title="Fritz Lang">Fritz Lang</a> on the <i>Boulevard of Stars</i> at Berlin's <a href="/wiki/Potsdamer_Platz" title="Potsdamer Platz">Potsdamer Platz</a>. Lang was the director of <a href="/wiki/Metropolis_(1927_film)" title="Metropolis (1927 film)">Metropolis</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> film (in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feature_length&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feature length (page does not exist)">feature length</a>), that premiered in 1927.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Germany" title="Cinema of Germany">German cinema</a> dates back to the earliest years of the medium, it has made major technical and artistic contributions to film, as with the work of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Max_Skladanowsky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Max Skladanowsky (page does not exist)">Max Skladanowsky</a>, who showed the first film sequences ever to an audience, in 1895. Early German cinema was particularly influential with <a href="/w/index.php?title=German_expressionism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="German expressionism (page does not exist)">German expressionists</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Wiene&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Wiene (page does not exist)">Robert Wiene</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Friedrich_Wilhelm_Murnau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau (page does not exist)">Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau</a>. Director <a href="/wiki/Fritz_Lang" title="Fritz Lang">Fritz Lang</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Metropolis_(1927_film)" title="Metropolis (1927 film)">Metropolis</a></i> (1927) is referred to as the first modern science-fiction film. In 1930 <a href="/wiki/Josef_von_Sternberg" title="Josef von Sternberg">Josef von Sternberg</a> directed <i><a href="/wiki/The_Blue_Angel" title="The Blue Angel">The Blue Angel</a></i>, the first major German <a href="/wiki/Sound_film" title="Sound film">sound film</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 1970s and 1980s, <a href="/wiki/New_German_Cinema" title="New German Cinema">New German Cinema</a> directors such as <a href="/wiki/Volker_Schl%C3%B6ndorff" title="Volker Schlöndorff">Volker Schlöndorff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Werner_Herzog" title="Werner Herzog">Werner Herzog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wim_Wenders" title="Wim Wenders">Wim Wenders</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rainer_Werner_Fassbinder" title="Rainer Werner Fassbinder">Rainer Werner Fassbinder</a> put West German cinema on the international stage.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup>  The annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Film_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Film Award (page does not exist)">European Film Awards</a> ceremony is held every other year in Berlin, home of the <a href="/wiki/European_Film_Academy" title="European Film Academy">European Film Academy</a> (EFA); the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berlin_Film_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berlin Film Festival (page does not exist)">Berlin Film Festival</a>, held annually since 1951, is one of the world's foremost film festivals.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, several German movies have had international success, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Nowhere_in_Africa" title="Nowhere in Africa">Nowhere in Africa</a></i> (2001), <i><a href="/wiki/Das_Experiment" title="Das Experiment">Das Experiment</a></i> (2001), <i><a href="/wiki/Good_Bye,_Lenin!" title="Good Bye, Lenin!">Good Bye, Lenin!</a></i> (2003), <i>Gegen die Wand (<a href="/wiki/Head-On" title="Head-On">Head-On</a>)</i> (2004), <i>Der Untergang (<a href="/wiki/Downfall_(2004_film)" title="Downfall (2004 film)">Downfall</a>)</i> (2004), <i><a href="/wiki/Perfume:_The_Story_of_a_Murderer" title="Perfume: The Story of a Murderer" class="mw-redirect">Perfume</a></i> (2006), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Baader_Meinhof_Complex&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Baader Meinhof Complex (page does not exist)">The Baader Meinhof Complex</a></i> (2008), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Wave_(2008_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Wave (2008 film) (page does not exist)">The Wave</a></i> (2008), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_White_Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The White Ribbon (page does not exist)">The White Ribbon</a></i> (2009), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pandorum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pandorum (page does not exist)">Pandorum</a></i> (2009), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Soul_Kitchen_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soul Kitchen (film) (page does not exist)">Soul Kitchen</a></i> (2009), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animals_United&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animals United (page does not exist)">Animals United</a><i> (2010), </i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Combat_Girls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Combat Girls (page does not exist)">Combat Girls</a><i> (2011) and </i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cloud_Atlas_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cloud Atlas (film) (page does not exist)">Cloud Atlas</a><i> (2012). The <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Foreign_Language_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film">Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film</a> went to the German production </i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Tin_Drum_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Tin Drum (film) (page does not exist)">Die Blechtrommel (The Tin Drum)</a><i> in 1979, to </i><a href="/wiki/Nowhere_in_Africa" title="Nowhere in Africa">Nowhere in Africa</a><i> in 2002, and to </i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Lives_of_Others&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Lives of Others (page does not exist)">Das Leben der Anderen (The Lives of Others)</a><i> in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup></i>
</p><p>Germany's television market is the largest in Europe, with some 34&#160;million TV households. Around 90% of German households have cable or satellite TV, with a variety of free-to-view public and commercial channels.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> The most watched television broadcast of all-time in Germany was the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 FIFA World Cup knockout stage (page does not exist)">Germany vs Spain</a> semi-fnal game of the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010 FIFA World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> Nine out of ten of the top ten <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_watched_television_broadcasts#Germany" title="List of most watched television broadcasts">most watched television broadcasts</a> of all-time in Germany feature the <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">German national football team</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Video_gaming_in_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Video gaming in Germany (page does not exist)">German video gaming market</a> is one of the largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gamescom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gamescom (page does not exist)">Gamescom</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cologne" title="Cologne">Cologne</a> is Europe's leading gaming convention. Popular game series from Germany include <a href="/wiki/Turrican" title="Turrican">Turrican</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anno_(series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anno (series) (page does not exist)">Anno series</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Settlers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Settlers (page does not exist)">The Settlers series</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gothic_series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gothic series (page does not exist)">Gothic series</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=SpellForce&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SpellForce (page does not exist)">SpellForce</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=X_(game_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="X (game series) (page does not exist)">X series</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=FIFA_Manager_(video_game_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FIFA Manager (video game series) (page does not exist)">FIFA Manager series</a>, <a href="/wiki/Far_Cry" title="Far Cry">Far Cry</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crysis (page does not exist)">Crysis</a>. The most relevant game developers and publishers are <a href="/wiki/Ascaron" title="Ascaron">Ascaron</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bigpoint_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bigpoint Games (page does not exist)">Bigpoint</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ubisoft_Blue_Byte" title="Ubisoft Blue Byte">Blue Byte</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crytek" title="Crytek">Crytek</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Deck13_Interactive&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deck13 Interactive (page does not exist)">Deck13</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deep_Silver" title="Deep Silver">Deep Silver</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=EA_Phenomic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="EA Phenomic (page does not exist)">EA Phenomic</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gameforge&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gameforge (page does not exist)">Gameforge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nintendo" title="Nintendo">Nintendo Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Piranha_Bytes" title="Piranha Bytes">Piranha Bytes</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radon_Labs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radon Labs (page does not exist)">Radon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Related_Designs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Related Designs (page does not exist)">Related</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spellbound_Entertainment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spellbound Entertainment (page does not exist)">Spellbound</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wooga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wooga (page does not exist)">Wooga</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hacker-Pschorr_Oktoberfest_Girl.jpg" title="File:Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest Girl.jpg">File:Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest Girl.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Bavaria" title="Bavaria">Bavarian</a> woman holding glasses of <a href="/wiki/Hacker-Pschorr" title="Hacker-Pschorr" class="mw-redirect">Hacker-Pschorr</a>, one of the few traditional <a href="/wiki/Beer" title="Beer">beer</a> brands that are allowed to be served at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oktoberfest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oktoberfest (page does not exist)">Oktoberfest</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>German cuisine varies from region to region. The southern regions of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bavarian_cuisine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bavarian cuisine (page does not exist)">Bavaria</a> and Swabia, for instance, share a culinary culture with Switzerland and Austria.  In all regions, meat is often eaten in sausage form.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Organic_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Organic food (page does not exist)">Organic food</a> has gained a market share of ca. 2%, and is expected to increase further.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> Although wine is becoming more popular in many parts of Germany, the national alcoholic drink is beer. German beer consumption per person is declining, but at 121.4&#160;litres in 2009 it is still among the highest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michelin_guide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michelin guide (page does not exist)">Michelin guide</a> has awarded nine restaurants in Germany three stars, the highest designation, while 15 more received two stars.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> German restaurants have become the world's second-most decorated after France.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pork&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pork (page does not exist)">Pork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">beef</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">poultry</a> are the main varieties of meat consumed in Germany, with pork being the most popular. The average person in Germany will consume up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of meat in a year. Among poultry, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chicken_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chicken (food) (page does not exist)">chicken</a> is most common, although <a href="/w/index.php?title=Duck_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Duck (food) (page does not exist)">duck</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goose" title="Goose">goose</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Domesticated_turkey" title="Domesticated turkey">turkey</a> are also enjoyed. <a href="/wiki/Game_(food)" title="Game (food)">Game meats</a>, especially <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boar (page does not exist)">boar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rabbit" title="Rabbit">rabbit</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Venison" title="Venison">venison</a> are also widely available all year round. <a href="/wiki/Trout" title="Trout">Trout</a> is the most common freshwater fish on the German menu; <a href="/wiki/Pike_(fish)" title="Pike (fish)" class="mw-redirect">pike</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carp" title="Carp">carp</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_perch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European perch (page does not exist)">European perch</a> also are listed frequently. Vegetables are often used in <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stews</a> or vegetable soups, but are also served as side dishes. Carrots, turnips, spinach, peas, beans, broccoli and many types of cabbage are very common. A wide variety of <a href="/wiki/Cake" title="Cake">cakes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tart" title="Tart">tarts</a> are served throughout the country, most commonly made with fresh fruit. Apples, plums, strawberries, and cherries are used regularly in cakes. <a href="/wiki/Cheesecake" title="Cheesecake">Cheesecake</a> is also very popular, often made with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quark_(cheese)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quark (cheese) (page does not exist)">quark</a>. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Schwarzw%C3%A4lder_Kirschtorte&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schwarzwälder Kirschtorte (page does not exist)">Schwarzwälder Kirschtorte</a></i> (Black Forest cake, made with cherries) is probably the most well-known example of a wide variety of typically German <a href="/w/index.php?title=Torte&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torte (page does not exist)">tortes</a> filled with whipped or butter cream.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:FIFA_WC-qualification_2014_-_Austria_vs._Germany_2012-09-11_(03).jpg" title="File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs. Germany 2012-09-11 (03).jpg">File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs. Germany 2012-09-11 (03).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany national football team</a> in 2012. <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular sport in Germany.</div></div></div>
<p>Twenty-seven million Germans are members of a sports club and an additional twelve million pursue sports individually.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-216">[216]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> is the most popular sport. With more than 6.3&#160;million official members, the <a href="/wiki/German_Football_Association" title="German Football Association">German Football Association</a> (<i>Deutscher Fußball-Bund</i>) is the largest sports organisation of its kind worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_216-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-216">[216]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fu%C3%9Fball-Bundesliga&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fußball-Bundesliga (page does not exist)">Bundesliga</a>, the top league of German football, is the most popular sports league in Germany and attracts the second highest <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_attendance_figures_at_domestic_professional_sports_leagues&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of attendance figures at domestic professional sports leagues (page does not exist)">average attendance</a> of any professional sports league in the world.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">German national football team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> in 1954, 1974 and 1990 and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=UEFA_European_Football_Championship&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UEFA European Football Championship (page does not exist)">UEFA European Football Championship</a> in 1972, 1980 and 1996. Germany hosted the FIFA World Cup in <a href="/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_1974&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FIFA World Cup 1974 (page does not exist)">1974</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=FIFA_World_Cup_2006&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FIFA World Cup 2006 (page does not exist)">2006</a> and the UEFA European Football Championship in <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1988" title="UEFA Euro 1988">1988</a>. Among the most well-known footballers are <a href="/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer" title="Franz Beckenbauer">Franz Beckenbauer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller" title="Gerd Müller">Gerd Müller</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C3%BCrgen_Klinsmann" title="Jürgen Klinsmann">Jürgen Klinsmann</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lothar_Matth%C3%A4us" title="Lothar Matthäus">Lothar Matthäus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Kahn" title="Oliver Kahn">Oliver Kahn</a>. Other popular spectator sports include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Team_handball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Team handball (page does not exist)">handball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sports_216-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sports-216">[216]</a></sup>
</p><p>Germany is one of the leading motor sports countries in the world. Constructors like <a href="/wiki/BMW" title="BMW">BMW</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mercedes-Benz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mercedes-Benz (page does not exist)">Mercedes</a> are prominent manufacturers in motor sport. Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Porsche" title="Porsche">Porsche</a> has won the <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="24 Hours of Le Mans">24 Hours of Le Mans</a>, an annual endurance race held in France, 16 times, and <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">Audi</a> has won it 11 times. The <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> driver <a href="/wiki/Michael_Schumacher" title="Michael Schumacher">Michael Schumacher</a> has set many motor sport records during his career, having won more <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions (page does not exist)">Formula One World Drivers' Championships</a> and more Formula One races than any other driver; he is one of the highest paid sportsmen in history.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historically, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Germany_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Germany at the Olympics (page does not exist)">German sportsmen</a> have been successful contenders in the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>, ranking third in an <a href="/w/index.php?title=All-time_Olympic_Games_medal_count&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All-time Olympic Games medal count (page does not exist)">all-time Olympic Games medal count</a>, combining East and West German medals. In the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a>, Germany finished fifth in the medal count,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> while in the <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> they finished first.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> Germany has hosted the Summer Olympic Games twice, in Berlin in <a href="/wiki/1936_Summer_Olympics" title="1936 Summer Olympics">1936</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Munich" title="Munich">Munich</a> in <a href="/wiki/1972_Summer_Olympics" title="1972 Summer Olympics">1972</a>. The Winter Olympic Games took place in Germany once in <a href="/wiki/1936_Winter_Olympics" title="1936 Winter Olympics">1936</a> in the twin towns of <a href="/wiki/Garmisch" title="Garmisch" class="mw-redirect">Garmisch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partenkirchen" title="Partenkirchen" class="mw-redirect">Partenkirchen</a>.
</p>

</p>

</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ucblibraries.colorado.edu/govpubs/for/germany.htm">Germany</a> at <i>UCB Libraries GovPubs</i>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Dmoz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Dmoz (page does not exist)">Template:Dmoz</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tatsachen-ueber-deutschland.de/en/">Facts about Germany</a> – by the German Federal Foreign Office
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.destatis.de/EN/Homepage.html">Destatis.de</a> – Federal Statistical Office Germany
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Osmrelation-inline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Osmrelation-inline (page does not exist)">Template:Osmrelation-inline</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ifs.du.edu/ifs/frm_CountryProfile.aspx?Country=DE">Key Development Forecasts for Germany</a> from <a href="/w/index.php?title=International_Futures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="International Futures (page does not exist)">International Futures</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Government
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bundesregierung.de/Webs/Breg/EN/Homepage/_node.html">Official site of the Government</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bundespraesident.de/EN/Home/home_node.html">Official site of the Federal Presidents</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.bundeskanzlerin.de/Webs/BK/En/Homepage/home.html">Official site of German Chancellor</a>
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Tourism
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.germany.travel/en/index.html">Official Germany Tourism Website</a>
</li>
</ul>
